title: My First Cybersecurity Job Fucking Sucked

paras.en: My first cybersecurity job was actually not what I thought it was gonna be. It was not what anyone told me cybersecurity was gonna be. And yeah, there should just be more information, more transparency out there around these entry-level "cybersecurity jobs."
paras.cn: 我的第一份网络安全工作实际上和我当初想的完全不一样。它和任何人告诉我的网络安全工作也完全不一样。而且，是的，关于这些入门级的“网络安全工作”，外界应该有更多的信息和透明度。

vocab.ex: This party is gonna be awesome.
vocab.tr: 这个派对将会超赞的。

vocab.ex: The company values transparency in all its business dealings.
vocab.tr: 该公司在所有商业往来中都重视透明度。

vocab.ex: He's looking for an entry-level position in marketing.
vocab.tr: 他正在寻找一个市场营销方面的入门级职位。

paras.en: So I got my first cybersecurity job like a year after I graduated college. Had a hard time finding a job, went on LinkedIn, posted on LinkedIn. This dude who ran an MSP (managed service provider) saw it and was like, "Do you want to work for my MSP?" And I was like, "Sure, I'm desperate." Long story short—if you want the longer explanation, there's a video on my channel—but yeah, posted on LinkedIn, MSP owner saw it, hired me to work for his MSP.
paras.cn: 所以我在大学毕业大约一年后得到了我的第一份网络安全工作。找工作很困难，我上了领英，在领英上发了帖子。一个经营MSP（管理服务提供商）的哥们看到了，然后就说：“你想为我的MSP工作吗？” 我当时就说：“当然，我急需工作。” 长话短说——如果你想要更长的解释，我频道上有个视频——但总之，在领英上发帖，MSP老板看到了，就雇我去他的MSP工作。

vocab.ex: She's having a hard time adjusting to her new school.
vocab.tr: 她正经历着适应新学校的困难时期。

vocab.ex: Hey dude, what's up?
vocab.tr: 嘿，哥们，怎么样？

vocab.ex: Our company outsources its IT support to a local MSP.
vocab.tr: 我们公司将其IT支持外包给了一家本地的管理服务提供商。

vocab.mean: （因急需而）不顾一切的；绝望的
vocab.ex: After losing his job, he was desperate for any kind of work.
vocab.tr: 失业后，他急需任何类型的工作。

vocab.ex: We had a lot of issues with the car, but long story short, we finally made it home.
vocab.tr: 我们的车出了很多问题，但长话短说，我们最终还是到家了。

paras.en: While I was working for his MSP, I was also doing a day job as an information technology teacher. So he kind of brought me on, didn't pay me for six months because I had to “learn the ropes” or whatever. Yeah, just did a bunch of help desk with no pay. And then six months later, I got paid $25 an hour to do help desk.
paras.cn: 在为他的MSP工作的同时，我还有一份信息技术老师的日间工作。所以他算是把我招进来了，但六个月没给我发工资，因为我得“摸清门道”什么的。是的，就是白干了一堆服务台的工作。然后六个月后，我才拿到每小时25美元的报酬来做服务台。

vocab.mean: （相对于副业或爱好的）本职工作
vocab.ex: He's a musician at night, but his day job is an accountant.
vocab.tr: 他晚上是音乐家，但他的本职工作是会计。

vocab.ex: The company decided to bring on a new marketing specialist.
vocab.tr: 公司决定招募一位新的市场专员。

vocab.ex: It took him a few weeks to learn the ropes at his new job.
vocab.tr: 他花了几周时间才熟悉了新工作的门道。

vocab.ex: We can watch a movie, play a game, or whatever.
vocab.tr: 我们可以看电影、玩游戏，或者做些别的事。

vocab.ex: If you have a problem with your computer, you should call the IT help desk.
vocab.tr: 如果你的电脑有问题，你应该打电话给IT服务台。

paras.en: But also, if you’re at a small company, you know, you have to wear a lot of hats. So I was doing help desk, security stuff, setting up SIEMs, security tool testing, testing EDRs, setting up detection rules, going to conferences, sales engineering, analyzing vulnerabilities and then communicating them to clients… and still doing help desk—all while getting paid $52,000 a year.
paras.cn: 而且，如果你在一家小公司，你知道，你得身兼数职。所以我当时在做服务台、安全方面的东西、搭建SIEM、安全工具测试、测试EDR、设置检测规则、参加会议、销售工程、分析漏洞然后与客户沟通……还一直在做服务台——所有这些工作，年薪只有52000美元。

vocab.ex: As a small business owner, she has to wear a lot of hats, from marketing to accounting.
vocab.tr: 作为一名小企业主，她必须身兼数职，从市场营销到会计都要管。

vocab.ex: I have a lot of stuff to do this weekend.
vocab.tr: 我这个周末有很多事情要做。

vocab.mean: 安全信息和事件管理系统
vocab.ex: The security team uses a SIEM to monitor network activity for threats.
vocab.tr: 安全团队使用SIEM来监控网络活动以发现威胁。

vocab.ex: Our company installed a new EDR solution to protect employee laptops.
vocab.tr: 我们公司安装了一个新的EDR解决方案来保护员工的笔记本电脑。

vocab.ex: The software update fixed a critical security vulnerability.
vocab.tr: 软件更新修复了一个严重的安全漏洞。

paras.en: So I was working like four hours a night on help desk with no pay. Six months later, got hired under contract at $52,000 a year, then was doing all the stuff I listed. And then I was like, "Hey, I can't afford to live. $52,000 in the US doesn’t get you very far." So I asked, "Is there a way I could get a raise so I can afford to live?" Because at the time I was living in my parents’ basement—you can’t really afford anything on that salary. Can’t pay bills, can’t pay rent.
paras.cn: 所以当时我每晚在服务台白干四小时。六个月后，以每年52000美元的合同被雇佣，然后就在做我列出的所有事情。再然后我就想，“嘿，我活不下去了。在美国52000美元根本干不了什么。” 于是我问：“有没有可能给我加薪，好让我能活下去？” 因为那时我住在我父母的地下室——靠那点薪水你真的什么也负担不起。付不起账单，付不起房租。

vocab.ex: The athlete is under contract with the team for another three years.
vocab.tr: 那位运动员与该队还有三年的合同。

vocab.ex: With rising prices, many people are struggling to afford to live in the city.
vocab.tr: 随着物价上涨，许多人在城市里难以负担生活。

vocab.ex: A little bit of knowledge on this subject won't get you very far; you need to be an expert.
vocab.tr: 对这个学科只有一点点知识没什么用；你需要成为专家。

vocab.ex: He asked his boss for a raise after working there for a year.
vocab.tr: 在那里工作一年后，他向老板提出了加薪请求。

vocab.ex: They converted their basement into a home gym.
vocab.tr: 他们把地下室改造成了家庭健身房。

paras.en: So I said, "Hey, could I perhaps get a raise for all the stuff I'm doing?" And he was like, "Yeah, yeah, we don’t have it in the budget, we’ll talk about it, blah blah blah." That went on for like four months. So naturally, I started applying to other jobs.
paras.cn: 于是我说：“嘿，鉴于我做的所有这些事，我或许能加薪吗？” 他就说：“嗯，嗯，我们预算里没这笔钱，我们会讨论的，诸如此类。” 这事拖了大概四个月。所以我很自然地，就开始申请其他工作了。

vocab.ex: Perhaps we can meet for lunch tomorrow.
vocab.tr: 或许我们明天可以一起吃午饭。

vocab.ex: A new coffee machine is not in the budget this year.
vocab.tr: 今年预算里没有买新咖啡机的计划。

vocab.mean: 诸如此类（表示不重要或不耐烦）
vocab.ex: He went on about his vacation, the hotel, the food, blah blah blah.
vocab.tr: 他不停地讲他的假期、酒店、食物，诸如此类。

vocab.ex: The meeting seemed to go on forever.
vocab.tr: 那场会议好像永远开不完似的。

vocab.ex: She decided to apply to several universities.
vocab.tr: 她决定申请几所大学。

paras.en: I got a job offer from another MSP the day we were flying back from a conference. So I sent him the job offer and said, "Hey, these guys need an answer today. They’re going to pay me $75,000 a year to be a GRC analyst, in a sense. I need to make more money, so just letting you know—they sent me an offer."
paras.cn: 就在我们从一个会议飞回来的那天，我收到了另一家MSP的工作录用。于是我把录用通知发给他，说：“嘿，这些人今天就要答复。他们准备付我每年75000美元，让我当一名GRC分析师，某种意义上是这样。我需要赚更多钱，所以就是让你知道一下——他们给了我一份录用通知。”

vocab.ex: After the final interview, she received a job offer from the company.
vocab.tr: 最后一轮面试后，她收到了公司的工作录用通知。

vocab.ex: He is attending a business conference in another city.
vocab.tr: 他正在另一个城市参加一个商务会议。

vocab.mean: 治理、风险与合规分析师
vocab.ex: As a GRC analyst, her job is to ensure the company follows industry regulations.
vocab.tr: 作为一名GRC分析师，她的工作是确保公司遵守行业法规。

vocab.ex: In a sense, he was right, but he didn't see the whole picture.
vocab.tr: 在某种意义上，他是对的，但他没有看到全局。

vocab.ex: I'm heading out now, just letting you know.
vocab.tr: 我现在要出门了，就是让你知道一下。

paras.en: And then he was like, "Oh, we can actually match that. I’ll start paying you $75,000 a year." We magically just got money. So that’s how that got negotiated. I stayed with that MSP, he paid me $75,000 a year, and then I moved on to other things after that.
paras.cn: 然后他就说：“哦，我们其实可以匹配那个薪资。我开始付你每年75000美元。” 我们就神奇地有了钱。事情就是这么谈妥的。我留在了那家MSP，他付我每年75000美元，那之后我又去做了别的事情。

vocab.ex: If you get a better offer, my company might be able to match it.
vocab.tr: 如果你得到更好的录用条件，我的公司也许能匹配。

vocab.ex: The missing keys magically reappeared on the kitchen counter.
vocab.tr: 丢失的钥匙神奇地重新出现在了厨房台面上。

vocab.ex: He was able to negotiate a higher salary before accepting the job.
vocab.tr: 在接受工作前，他成功地谈下了一个更高的薪水。

vocab.ex: After finishing the first task, let's move on to the next one.
vocab.tr: 完成第一个任务后，我们继续下一个吧。

paras.en: But yeah, all the while, I was configuring EDRs, SIEMs, security tool testing, doing vulnerability scanning, some penetration testing for compliance, finding vulnerabilities in client systems from our SIEM, then communicating that to them to try and upsell cybersecurity services.
paras.cn: 但是，是的，一直以来，我都在配置EDR、SIEM、做安全工具测试、进行漏洞扫描、为合规性做一些渗透测试、从我们的SIEM中发现客户系统的漏洞，然后与他们沟通，试图向上销售网络安全服务。

vocab.ex: He was pretending to listen, but all the while he was thinking about his vacation.
vocab.tr: 他假装在听，但其实一直都在想他的假期。

vocab.ex: You need to configure the new software before you can use it.
vocab.tr: 在使用新软件前，你需要先配置它。

vocab.ex: Regular vulnerability scanning is a key part of network security.
vocab.tr: 定期的漏洞扫描是网络安全的关键部分。

vocab.ex: The company hired a firm to perform penetration testing on their new application.
vocab.tr: 该公司雇佣了一家公司对他们的新应用进行渗透测试。

vocab.ex: All our products are in compliance with international safety standards.
vocab.tr: 我们所有的产品都符合国际安全标准。

vocab.mean: 向上销售（劝说顾客买更贵的东西）
vocab.ex: The car salesman tried to upsell me to a more expensive model.
vocab.tr: 汽车销售员试图劝我买一款更贵的车型。

paras.en: So yeah, definitely a journey. And definitely not what I thought. When I thought I was getting into cybersecurity, I thought I’d be sitting behind a desk looking at logs all day—which in a bigger company, yeah sure, if you're in a SOC. But if you're at a very small company—and I’ve always worked for very small companies—you wear a lot of hats, and you just do a lot of things. It’s good for learning, but then you're like, "I need money to live." Sometimes money outweighs learning.
paras.cn: 所以，是的，这绝对是一段旅程。而且绝对不是我想的那样。当我以为我要进入网络安全领域时，我以为我会整天坐在办公桌后面看日志——在更大的公司里，是的，当然，如果你在SOC（安全运营中心）。但如果你在一家非常小的公司——而我一直都在为非常小的公司工作——你就得身兼数职，做很多事情。这对学习有好处，但然后你就会想：“我需要钱来生活。” 有时候，金钱比学习更重要。

vocab.ex: Learning a new language is a long but rewarding journey.
vocab.tr: 学习一门新语言是一段漫长但有益的旅程。

vocab.ex: She was excited to get into the field of renewable energy.
vocab.tr: 她对能进入可再生能源领域感到兴奋。

vocab.ex: The system administrator checked the server logs for any errors.
vocab.tr: 系统管理员检查了服务器日志以查找任何错误。

vocab.ex: A SOC analyst monitors security alerts 24/7.
vocab.tr: 安全运营中心分析师全天候监控安全警报。

vocab.ex: For this job, the benefits far outweigh the long hours.
vocab.tr: 对这份工作而言，福利远比长工作时间更重要。

paras.en: So yeah, it’s just not really what I thought it was. Doesn’t mean it’s bad—just means it’s different. But now, as everyone knows, I’ve been doing content stuff, tech content, which has started to actually pay more than my monthly salary at my current job. So that’s great, really like that. You know, there’s a bright side to most things.
paras.cn: 所以，是的，它真的不是我想的那样。但这不意味着它不好——只是意味着它不一样。但现在，大家都知道，我一直在做内容方面的东西，科技内容，而这实际上已经开始比我目前工作的月薪付得更多了。所以那太棒了，真的很喜欢。你知道，大多数事情都有光明的一面。

vocab.ex: Just because he's quiet, it doesn't mean he's unfriendly.
vocab.tr: 他安静不意味着他不友好。

vocab.ex: She creates educational content for her YouTube channel.
vocab.tr: 她为她的YouTube频道创作教育内容。

vocab.ex: He was offered a higher salary at the new company.
vocab.tr: 新公司给了他更高的薪水。

vocab.ex: Even though he lost the game, he tried to look on the bright side and focus on what he learned.
vocab.tr: 尽管他输了比赛，他还是努力往好的方面看，专注于他学到的东西。

paras.en: So yeah, that’s just the story about how my first cybersecurity paycheck fucking sucked. And they definitely don’t pay you as much as you think they’re going to pay you.
paras.cn: 所以，是的，那只是关于我第一份网络安全薪水有多他妈的烂的故事。而且他们绝对不会付你想象中那么多的钱。

vocab.ex: He looks forward to his paycheck at the end of every month.
vocab.tr: 他盼望着每个月底的薪水。

vocab.ex: This movie really sucks; let's watch something else.
vocab.tr: 这部电影真的烂透了，我们看点别的吧。

vocab.ex: The job isn't as much fun as you think it is.
vocab.tr: 这份工作没你想象的那么有趣。

paras.en: Yeah, so that’s it. Sorry, it’s a little rambly—I’m just at this park. I’m traveling, scootering around the city, found a park, popped a squat, figured I’d film a video.
paras.cn: 是的，就是这样。抱歉，有点啰嗦——我只是在这个公园里。我正在旅行，骑着滑板车在城里转悠，发现一个公园，随便找个地方一蹲，就想着拍个视频。

vocab.ex: I've explained everything. So, that's it.
vocab.tr: 我已经解释了所有事。所以，就是这样。

vocab.ex: His speech was a bit rambly and hard to follow.
vocab.tr: 他的演讲有点啰嗦，很难跟上思路。

vocab.ex: The kids love to scooter around the neighborhood.
vocab.tr: 孩子们喜欢在社区里骑滑板车转悠。

vocab.mean: （俚语）随便找个地方蹲下/坐下
vocab.ex: Let's just pop a squat on the grass and enjoy the sun.
vocab.tr: 我们就在草地上随便坐下，享受阳光吧。

paras.en: So yeah, make sure to like, subscribe, punch all the buttons in the face as always… and I’ll see you in the next one.
paras.cn: 所以，是的，确保点赞、订阅、像往常一样把所有按钮都给捶一遍……我们下个视频见。

vocab.ex: Please make sure to lock the door when you leave.
vocab.tr: 离开时请务必锁门。

vocab.ex: If you like the content, don't forget to subscribe to the channel.
vocab.tr: 如果你喜欢这些内容，别忘了订阅这个频道。

vocab.ex: He was so frustrated with the vending machine that he wanted to punch it in the face.
vocab.tr: 他对那台自动售货机感到非常沮丧，很想给它一拳。
match: punch all the buttons in the face

vocab.word: see you in the next one
vocab.ex: Thanks for watching, and I'll see you in the next one.
vocab.tr: 感谢收看，我们下个视频见。
match: see you in the next one

title: You Are Not Late, You Are Loading

paras.en: You ever notice how no one says it directly? But somehow the world makes you feel like if you didn't make it by 30, your life is basically a discount sale. It's like society has this invisible scoreboard. And the moment you cross 30, the referee blows a whistle like, "Alright buddy, time's up. Hand in your dreams."
paras.cn: 你有没有注意到，没有人会直说？但不知何故，这个世界让你觉得，如果你30岁还没成功，你的人生基本上就是一场清仓大甩卖。就好像社会有一个无形的记分牌。一旦你过了30岁，裁判就会吹响哨子，好像在说：‘好了，伙计，时间到。交出你的梦想吧。’

vocab.ex: After years of hard work, she finally made it as a successful novelist.
vocab.tr: 经过多年的努力，她终于成功地成为了一名成功的小说家。

vocab.ex: I bought this jacket for half price at a huge discount sale.
vocab.tr: 我是在一次大型清仓大甩卖时半价买的这件夹克。

vocab.ex: He felt like he was fighting against an invisible enemy.
vocab.tr: 他感觉自己仿佛在与一个无形的敌人战斗。

vocab.ex: The final score was displayed on the giant scoreboard.
vocab.tr: 最终比分显示在巨大的记分牌上。

vocab.ex: The referee blew his whistle to signal the end of the game.
vocab.tr: 裁判吹响哨子，示意比赛结束。

vocab.ex: The teacher announced, 'Time's up, please put your pens down.'
vocab.tr: 老师宣布：‘时间到，请放下你们的笔。’

paras.en: But here's the plot twist no one expects: You're not late. You're just early in a different story. Let me explain.
paras.cn: 但这是一个没人预料到的剧情反转：你没有迟到。你只是在另一个故事里来得早了。我来解释一下。

vocab.ex: The movie's plot twist at the end shocked the entire audience.
vocab.tr: 电影结尾的剧情反转震惊了所有观众。

vocab.ex: I didn't expect to see you here today!
vocab.tr: 我没预料到今天会在这里见到你！

paras.en: We live in a world where someone becomes famous at 19 for eating spicy noodles on camera. And suddenly everyone else feels like they've failed at life. Like, bro, I can't even handle mild spice. How was I supposed to compete?
paras.cn: 我们生活在一个19岁的人因为在镜头前吃辣面而出名的世界。然后突然之间，其他所有人都感觉自己的人生失败了。就像，哥们，我连微辣都受不了。我该怎么竞争？

vocab.ex: He challenged himself to eat the restaurant's spiciest noodles.
vocab.tr: 他挑战自己去吃那家餐厅最辣的面条。

vocab.ex: Just because you lost your job doesn't mean you've failed at life.
vocab.tr: 你丢了工作不代表你的人生就失败了。

vocab.ex: Hey bro, can you help me with this?
vocab.tr: 嘿，哥们，能帮我一下这个吗？

vocab.ex: She knows how to handle difficult customers with patience.
vocab.tr: 她知道如何有耐心地应对难缠的顾客。

vocab.ex: I prefer my food with just a mild spice.
vocab.tr: 我更喜欢我的食物只带一点微辣。

vocab.ex: She had to compete against hundreds of other applicants for the job.
vocab.tr: 她必须和几百名其他申请者竞争这份工作。

paras.en: Every time you scroll, it feels like the entire planet is winning except you. Someone your age bought a house. Someone younger than you bought two houses. And you're sitting there proud because you finally fixed your sleep schedule for one day.
paras.cn: 每次你刷手机，都感觉好像除了你，整个地球都在赢。一个和你同龄的人买了房子。一个比你年轻的人买了两套房子。而你却坐在那里，因为终于把自己的睡眠时间调整好了一天而感到自豪。

vocab.ex: He spent hours just scrolling through social media.
vocab.tr: 他花了好几个小时就在刷社交媒体。

vocab.ex: Maintaining a consistent sleep schedule is important for your health.
vocab.tr: 保持一个固定的睡眠时间表对你的健康很重要。

paras.en: But here's the truth: You didn't miss your moment. Your moment is being built quietly.
paras.cn: 但真相是：你没有错过你的时刻。你的时刻正在被悄悄地构建。

vocab.ex: He hesitated for too long and missed his moment to ask her out.
vocab.tr: 他犹豫了太久，错过了约她出去的时机。

paras.en: Behind all the comparison and noise, see, we were trained to think speed equals success. That if you're not fast, you're finished. But speed is just a flex. Depth is the real power.
paras.cn: 在所有比较和噪音的背后，你看，我们被训练去认为速度等于成功。如果你不够快，你就完蛋了。但速度只是一种炫耀。深度才是真正的力量。

vocab.ex: Constant comparison with others can lead to unhappiness.
vocab.tr: 不断地与他人比较会导致不快乐。

vocab.ex: In this equation, X equals Y plus Z.
vocab.tr: 在这个等式中，X等于Y加Z。

vocab.ex: Buying that expensive car was just a flex to show off his wealth.
vocab.tr: 买那辆昂贵的车只是为了炫耀他的财富。

vocab.ex: His new book has a surprising emotional depth.
vocab.tr: 他的新书有着令人惊讶的情感深度。

paras.en: Think about it. When you were younger, you wanted everything fast. Fast results. Fast money. Fast answers. Fast Wi-Fi. (Still valid today.) But fast success is like fast food. Looks good, feels good, but collapses under pressure.
paras.cn: 想想看。你年轻的时候，什么都想要快的。快的结果。快的钱。快的答案。快的Wi-Fi。（今天仍然有效。）但快速的成功就像快餐。看起来不错，感觉很好，但在压力下就会崩溃。

vocab.ex: The final result of the experiment was unexpected.
vocab.tr: 实验的最终结果出人意料。

vocab.ex: Your passport is no longer valid; you need to renew it.
vocab.tr: 你的护照不再有效了；你需要更新它。

vocab.ex: The young athlete collapsed under the pressure of the championship match.
vocab.tr: 那位年轻运动员在冠军赛的压力下崩溃了。

paras.en: Real success? It cooks slow. Like those dishes your mom makes that take hours. But slap 100 times harder. You are that dish.
paras.cn: 真正的成功？它是慢炖出来的。就像你妈妈做的那些需要花好几个小时的菜。但味道要好上100倍。你就是那道菜。

vocab.ex: To make the meat really tender, you have to cook it slow for several hours.
vocab.tr: 为了让肉变得非常嫩，你必须慢炖好几个小时。

vocab.mean: （俚语，用于食物）味道极好；超赞
vocab.ex: This pizza is amazing; it really slaps.
vocab.tr: 这个披萨太棒了，味道超赞。

paras.en: And here's another thing no one talks about: Nobody tells you how many people peak early and then fall flat because their confidence was built on applause, not on identity.
paras.cn: 还有一件没人谈论的事：没人告诉你，有多少人年少成名，然后一败涂地，因为他们的自信是建立在掌声之上，而不是身份认同之上。

vocab.ex: Many child actors peak early and struggle to find success as adults.
vocab.tr: 许多童星过早达到顶峰，成年后却难以找到成功。

vocab.ex: His attempt at a joke completely fell flat; no one laughed.
vocab.tr: 他想讲个笑话，但彻底失败了，没人笑。

vocab.ex: The audience gave the performers a long round of applause.
vocab.tr: 观众为表演者们献上了长久的一轮掌声。

vocab.ex: Finding your own identity is an important part of growing up.
vocab.tr: 找到你自己的身份认同是成长的重要部分。

paras.en: Life is not a race. It's a rhythm. And yours is not late. It's layered.
paras.cn: 人生不是一场赛跑。它是一种节奏。而你的节奏不是晚了。它是富有层次的。

vocab.ex: He tried to turn his career into a race against his colleagues.
vocab.tr: 他试图把自己的职业生涯变成一场与同事的赛跑。

vocab.ex: It's important to find your own working rhythm and not compare yourself to others.
vocab.tr: 重要的是找到你自己的工作节奏，而不是和别人比较。

vocab.ex: Her personality is very layered; there's more to her than you first see.
vocab.tr: 她的个性非常富有层次；她比你初见时要复杂得多。

paras.en: Let me give you a simple example. Have you ever tried to open a stubborn jar? You twist it, twist it again. Nothing. Someone else comes, taps it twice, opens it easily. And you feel weak like, "Wow. Okay."
paras.cn: 我给你举个简单的例子。你试过打开一个拧不开的罐子吗？你拧它，再拧一次。没用。别人过来，敲两下，轻松打开了。然后你感觉自己很弱，心想：“哇。好吧。”

vocab.ex: I couldn't open the stubborn lid of the jar.
vocab.tr: 我打不开那个拧不开的罐子盖。

vocab.ex: She opened a jar of pickles.
vocab.tr: 她打开了一罐泡菜。

vocab.ex: You need to twist the cap to open the bottle.
vocab.tr: 你需要拧一下瓶盖才能打开瓶子。

vocab.ex: She was tapping her fingers on the desk impatiently.
vocab.tr: 她不耐烦地用手指敲着桌子。

paras.en: But you know what actually happened? All the work was done by you. They just showed up at the right moment. That's your life. You've been building pressure, strength, experience, depth. You're not stuck. You're marinating.
paras.cn: 但你知道实际发生了什么吗？所有的工作都是你做的。他们只是在正确的时刻出现而已。那就是你的人生。你一直在积累压力、力量、经验、深度。你没有停滞不前。你正在腌制入味。

vocab.ex: He didn't show up for the meeting, and no one knew why.
vocab.tr: 他没有出席会议，没人知道为什么。

vocab.ex: His new book has a surprising emotional depth.
vocab.tr: 他的新书有着令人惊讶的情感深度。

vocab.ex: I feel stuck in this boring job and need a change.
vocab.tr: 我感觉被困在这份无聊的工作里，需要改变。

vocab.mean: 腌制（此处比喻酝酿、准备）
vocab.ex: Instead of rushing, he let the ideas marinate in his mind for a few days.
vocab.tr: 他没有急于求成，而是让那些想法在他的脑海里酝酿了好几天。

paras.en: You know who wasn't late? Colonel Sanders, 65 when KFC took off. Vera Wang, 40 when she designed her first dress. Morgan Freeman, 52 when he got his first breakout role. Imagine if they said, "Nah, it's too late. Pass me the remote."
paras.cn: 你知道谁不晚吗？桑德斯上校，65岁时肯德基才起飞。王薇薇，40岁时设计了她的第一件婚纱。摩根·弗里曼，52岁时才得到他第一个突破性的角色。想象一下，如果他们说：“算了，太晚了。把遥控器给我吧。”

vocab.ex: Her acting career really took off after that movie.
vocab.tr: 那部电影之后，她的演艺事业真正起飞了。

vocab.ex: That was the breakout role that made him a Hollywood star.
vocab.tr: 那是让他成为好莱坞明星的那个突破性角色。

vocab.ex: A: 'Want to go to the movies?' B: 'Nah, I'm too tired.'
vocab.tr: A：“想去看电影吗？” B：“不了，我太累了。”

vocab.ex: Can you pass me the TV remote?
vocab.tr: 能把电视遥控器递给我吗？

paras.en: They didn't bloom late. They bloomed when they were finally ready. And maybe that's you. Maybe you had to go through all that confusion. All those wrong turns. All those silent years, not because you were failing, but because life was preparing you for something bigger than what your 20-year-old self could handle.
paras.cn: 他们不是开花晚了。他们是在他们终于准备好时才开花的。也许你也是这样。也许你必须经历所有那些困惑。所有那些弯路。所有那些沉寂的岁月，不是因为你在失败，而是因为生活在为你准备一些比你20岁的自己所能承受的更宏大的事情。

vocab.ex: She was a talented artist who didn't truly bloom until she was in her fifties.
vocab.tr: 她是一位才华横溢的艺术家，直到五十多岁才真正大放异彩。

vocab.ex: There was a lot of confusion about the new rules.
vocab.tr: 关于新规则有很多困惑。

vocab.ex: Taking that job was a wrong turn in his career.
vocab.tr: 接受那份工作是他职业生涯中的一个弯路。

vocab.ex: She knows how to handle difficult customers with patience.
vocab.tr: 她知道如何有耐心地应对难缠的顾客。

paras.en: You ever noticed people who succeed early get shaken by the smallest failure? One bad comment and they spiral. One bad day and they vanish. But you? You've already lived through storms. You don't break easily. You bend, you complain, you eat biryani, but you come back. That's your superpower.
paras.cn: 你有没有注意到那些早早成功的人，会被最小的失败所动摇？一句差评，他们就陷入螺旋。糟糕的一天，他们就消失了。但你呢？你已经经历过风暴了。你不会轻易被打垮。你会弯曲，你会抱怨，你会吃印度香饭，但你会回来。那就是你的超能力。

vocab.ex: He was visibly shaken after the accident.
vocab.tr: 事故过后，他显然受到了惊吓。

vocab.ex: After losing his job, he started to spiral into depression.
vocab.tr: 失业后，他开始螺旋式地陷入抑郁。

vocab.ex: The magician made the rabbit vanish in a puff of smoke.
vocab.tr: 魔术师让兔子在一阵烟雾中消失了。

vocab.ex: The strong winds made the trees bend.
vocab.tr: 强风使树木弯曲。

vocab.ex: If you could have any superpower, what would it be?
vocab.tr: 如果你能拥有任何超能力，你想要什么？

paras.en: Here's something funny. When we think we're behind, we start acting like life is a race against our own imagination. A fictional version of ourselves we created at 17. "I should have been rich by now. I should have figured it out. I should have been in a different place."
paras.cn: 有件好笑的事。当我们认为自己落后时，我们就开始表现得好像人生是一场与我们自己想象力的赛跑。一个我们在17岁时创造出来的虚构版本的自己。“我现在本该有钱了。我本该搞定一切了。我本该在另一个地方了。”

vocab.ex: He felt like he was falling behind in his studies.
vocab.tr: 他感觉自己在学业上落后了。

vocab.ex: Sherlock Holmes is a famous fictional detective.
vocab.tr: 夏洛克·福尔摩斯是一位著名的虚构侦探。

vocab.ex: Don't worry, we'll figure it out together.
vocab.tr: 别担心，我们会一起搞定的。

paras.en: Says who? 17-year-old you? The same person who thought they would grow up and buy a Lamborghini with 200 rupees? Let that version go.
paras.cn: 谁说的？17岁的你？那个以为自己长大后能用200卢比买一辆兰博基尼的同一个人？放过那个版本的自己吧。

vocab.ex: "You can't do that!" "Says who?"
vocab.tr: “你不能那么做！”“谁说的？”

vocab.mean: 卢比（印度等国货币单位）
vocab.ex: A cup of chai on the street costs only a few rupees.
vocab.tr: 街边的一杯印度奶茶只需要几个卢比。

vocab.ex: It's time to let go of the past and focus on the future.
vocab.tr: 是时候放下过去，专注于未来了。

paras.en: Because here's the truth: You don't owe anything to the person you used to be. But you owe everything to the person you're becoming. And that person is waking up.
paras.cn: 因为真相是：你对过去的自己不亏欠任何东西。但你对正在成为的自己亏欠一切。而那个人正在醒来。

vocab.ex: I feel like I owe you an apology for what I said.
vocab.tr: 我觉得我为我说的话亏欠你一个道歉。

vocab.ex: It's time for people to wake up and see what's really happening.
vocab.tr: 是时候人们该觉醒，看看真正发生了什么。

paras.en: But there's one thing you must understand, and no one likes hearing this: Environment wins over willpower. You can read the best books, follow all the gurus, watch motivational videos every morning. But if every time you sit with people who tell you, "Be realistic, it's too late. You should stop dreaming," then you're basically charging your phone with 1% battery and calling it progress.
paras.cn: 但有一件事你必须明白，而且没人喜欢听这个：环境胜过意志力。你可以读最好的书，关注所有的大师，每天早上看励志视频。但如果每次你都和那些告诉你“现实点，太晚了。你应该别做梦了”的人坐在一起，那么你基本上就是在用1%的电量给手机充电，还称之为进步。

vocab.ex: It takes a lot of willpower to quit smoking.
vocab.tr: 戒烟需要很大的意志力。

vocab.ex: He is considered a marketing guru in the industry.
vocab.tr: 他被认为是行业内的营销大师。

vocab.ex: She starts her day by listening to a motivational podcast.
vocab.tr: 她以听一个励志播客开始她的一天。

vocab.ex: You need to set realistic goals that you can actually achieve.
vocab.tr: 你需要设定你能够真正实现的现实目标。

paras.en: Your environment is programming you. Softly, quietly, repeatedly, like a leaking tap shaping a stone. You don't have to cut people off. You just have to choose whose voice enters your mind. If someone constantly tells you your dreams are unrealistic, just smile politely and remember: They're not talking about your limits. They're talking about theirs.
paras.cn: 你的环境正在编程你。轻柔地，安静地，重复地，就像漏水的水龙头塑造一块石头。你不必切断与人的联系。你只需要选择谁的声音能进入你的思想。如果有人不断告诉你你的梦想不现实，只需礼貌地微笑，并记住：他们不是在谈论你的极限。他们是在谈论他们的。

vocab.ex: Society can program us to believe certain things from a young age.
vocab.tr: 社会可以从我们年幼时就编程我们去相信某些事情。

vocab.ex: The constant drip of the leaking tap drove him crazy.
vocab.tr: 漏水的水龙头持续的滴水声让他快疯了。

vocab.ex: Sometimes, for your own mental health, you have to cut off toxic people.
vocab.tr: 有时候，为了你自己的心理健康，你必须与有毒的人切断联系。

vocab.ex: Setting a goal to become a millionaire in one month is unrealistic.
vocab.tr: 设定一个月内成为百万富翁的目标是不现实的。

vocab.ex: He's always testing the limits of his own physical endurance.
vocab.tr: 他总是在测试自己身体耐力的极限。

paras.en: Here's what nobody tells you about real transformation: It happens quietly. No applause, no spotlight, no "bro you're changing." Nothing. It's that boring part of the movie where the hero trains alone. Fails alone, gets back up alone. But when he returns, he's unrecognizable.
paras.cn: 关于真正的转变，没人告诉你的是：它悄然发生。没有掌声，没有聚光灯，没有“哥们你变了”。什么都没有。就像电影里英雄独自训练的那个无聊部分。独自失败，独自站起来。但当他回归时，他已判若两人。

vocab.ex: The city has undergone a complete transformation in the last decade.
vocab.tr: 在过去十年里，这座城市经历了彻底的转变。

vocab.ex: The audience gave the performers a long round of applause.
vocab.tr: 观众为表演者们献上了长久的一轮掌声。

vocab.ex: As a famous actor, he was always in the public spotlight.
vocab.tr: 作为一名著名演员，他总是在公众的聚光灯下。

vocab.ex: Life will knock you down, but the important thing is to always get back up.
vocab.tr: 生活会把你击倒，但重要的是要永远重新站起来。

vocab.ex: After losing so much weight, he was almost unrecognizable to his old friends.
vocab.tr: 减了那么多体重后，他的老朋友们几乎都认不出他了。

paras.en: That's you right now. You feel invisible? Good. You feel lost? Perfect. You feel like no one sees your effort? Even better. Because silence is where legends are built. The world celebrates the breakthrough. But it ignores the rebuilding. What you're doing now, this messy, confusing, unglamorous inner work—that's the real transformation.
paras.cn: 那就是现在的你。你感觉自己被无视？很好。你感觉迷失？完美。你感觉没人看到你的努力？甚至更好。因为寂静是传奇诞生的地方。世界庆祝突破。但它忽略了重建。你现在所做的，这凌乱、困惑、毫无光彩的内在功课——那才是真正的转变。

vocab.ex: As a new employee, she often felt invisible in large meetings.
vocab.tr: 作为一名新员工，她在大хing会议中常常感觉自己被无视。

vocab.ex: He is a living legend in the world of basketball.
vocab.tr: 他是篮球界一个活着的传奇。

vocab.ex: The scientist's discovery was a major breakthrough in cancer research.
vocab.tr: 那位科学家的发现在癌症研究领域是一个重大突破。

vocab.ex: The process of learning can often be messy and nonlinear.
vocab.tr: 学习的过程常常可能是凌乱和非线性的。

vocab.ex: Cleaning the house is an unglamorous but necessary chore.
vocab.tr: 打扫房子是一件平凡但必要的家务。

vocab.ex: Therapy and meditation are important parts of his inner work.
vocab.tr: 心理治疗和冥想是他内心修行的重要部分。

paras.en: So if you feel like you're late, let me say this clearly: You are not late. You are loading. And when you return, you're not going to come back as who you were. You're going to come back as someone even you won't recognize.
paras.cn: 所以如果你感觉自己晚了，让我清楚地说明：你没有晚。你正在加载。而当你回归时，你不会再是过去的那个你。你将会以一个连你自己都认不出的身份回归。

vocab.ex: He explained the instructions so clearly that everyone understood.
vocab.tr: 他把说明解释得非常清楚，每个人都听懂了。

vocab.mean: 加载（此处比喻准备、积蓄力量）
vocab.ex: Please wait a moment while the game is loading.
vocab.tr: 请稍等片刻，游戏正在加载。

vocab.ex: After his long journey, he came back as a changed man.
vocab.tr: 长途旅行归来后，他判若两人。

vocab.ex: I didn't recognize him at first with his new haircut.
vocab.tr: 他剪了新发型，我第一眼没认出他。

paras.en: Not louder. Deeper. Not faster. Stronger. Not desperate. Destined.
paras.cn: 不是更响亮。而是更深沉。不是更快。而是更强壮。不是绝望。而是注定。

vocab.ex: His understanding of the subject became deeper after years of study.
vocab.tr: 经过多年的学习，他对这门学科的理解变得更深了。

vocab.ex: Regular exercise will make your muscles stronger.
vocab.tr: 定期锻炼会让你的肌肉更强壮。

vocab.ex: After losing his job, he felt desperate and alone.
vocab.tr: 失业后，他感到绝望和孤独。

vocab.ex: From a young age, it was clear she was destined for greatness.
vocab.tr: 从小时候起，就很明显她注定会成就一番伟业。

paras.en: Your story doesn't end in the dark. It begins there. And when you rise, you won't need to announce it. The world will notice. Because some people succeed early, but the ones who succeed later? They don't just rise. They redefine the entire game.
paras.cn: 你的故事不会在黑暗中结束。它从那里开始。而当你崛起时，你不需要宣告。世界会注意到。因为有些人成功得早，但那些后来成功的人呢？他们不止是崛起。他们重新定义了整个游戏。

vocab.ex: After years of struggle, she finally began to rise in her profession.
vocab.tr: 经过多年的奋斗，她终于在自己的专业领域开始崛起。

vocab.ex: The company will announce its quarterly earnings next week.
vocab.tr: 该公司将于下周公布其季度收益。

vocab.ex: Her groundbreaking research helped to redefine the field of physics.
vocab.tr: 她开创性的研究帮助重新定义了物理学领域。

paras.en: And that might be exactly who you are.
paras.cn: 而那可能正是你的本色。

vocab.ex: That's exactly what I was trying to say!
vocab.tr: 那正是我刚才想说的！

title: Starting Cybersecurity From Scratch: A NoBS Guide

paras.en: If I had to start cybersecurity from scratch, what would I do? Now for me, I learned the extremely hard way. I was actually unemployed for about a year and a half. I did everything I could to try and land a job in cybersecurity, and then I finally landed one—and I didn't even apply.
paras.cn: 如果我必须从零开始学习网络安全，我会怎么做？对我来说，我学得异常艰难。我实际上失业了大约一年半。我尽我所能地去尝试，想在网络安全领域找到一份工作，然后我最终找到了一份——而且我甚至都没有申请。

vocab.ex: He built his successful business from scratch.
vocab.tr: 他白手起家，建立了他成功的企业。

vocab.ex: Some people have to learn lessons the hard way, through their own mistakes.
vocab.tr: 有些人必须通过自己的错误，以艰难的方式吸取教训。

vocab.ex: After the factory closed, many workers in the town were unemployed.
vocab.tr: 工厂关闭后，镇上许多工人都失业了。

vocab.ex: It took him six months, but he finally managed to land a job in his field.
vocab.tr: 花了他六个月时间，但他最终还是设法在自己的领域找到了一份工作。

paras.en: So here are some things I would do if I could start over and maybe speed up the unemployment journey for past me—and maybe for current you.
paras.cn: 所以，如果我能重新来过，这里有一些我会做的事情，也许能为过去的我——也可能为现在的你——加速失业之旅的进程。

vocab.ex: After the project failed, the team had to start over from the beginning.
vocab.tr: 项目失败后，团队不得不从头开始。

vocab.ex: Can you try to speed up the process? We're running out of time.
vocab.tr: 你能试着加速这个过程吗？我们快没时间了。

paras.en: I have a bachelor's degree in cybersecurity, a boot camp certificate, Security+, and A+. I got all that and then landed a job. After landing the job, I got AZ-900 and Network+. I skipped Network+ in the beginning because I hated networking, and I was doing cybersecurity stuff without even knowing what a subnet was. So, yeah—definitely don’t skip networking. More on that in a second.
paras.cn: 我有一个网络安全学士学位，一个训练营证书，Security+和A+。我拿到了所有这些，然后找到了一份工作。找到工作后，我又考了AZ-900和Network+。我一开始跳过了Network+，因为我讨厌网络，而且我当时甚至不知道子网是什么就在做网络安全方面的事情。所以，是的——绝对不要跳过网络。稍后会详细说明。

vocab.ex: She earned a bachelor's degree in economics from a top university.
vocab.tr: 她在一所顶尖大学获得了经济学学士学位。

vocab.ex: He attended a coding boot camp to switch careers and become a developer.
vocab.tr: 他参加了一个编程训练营以转换职业，成为一名开发人员。

vocab.ex: If you don't like a chapter, you can just skip it and move to the next one.
vocab.tr: 如果你不喜欢某一章，你可以直接跳过它，进入下一章。

vocab.ex: The network administrator divided the large network into several smaller subnets.
vocab.tr: 网络管理员将大型网络分成了几个较小的子网。

vocab.word: more on that in a second
vocab.ex: I have a big announcement, but more on that in a second.
vocab.tr: 我有一个重大宣布，但稍后会详细说明。
match: More on that in a second

paras.en: To get into cybersecurity, you don’t really need a degree necessarily. If I could go back and do it, I would not do a boot camp, and I would not get a bachelor’s degree. The things they teach you in cybersecurity in college are very outdated and are, in my opinion, a bit of a waste of time—but that’s just me.
paras.cn: 要进入网络安全领域，你不一定真的需要一个学位。如果我能回去重来，我不会去训练营，也不会去读学士学位。他们在大学里教你的网络安全知识非常过时，在我看来，有点浪费时间——但这只是我个人的看法。

vocab.mean: 必然地；必定（常用于否定句）
vocab.ex: A higher price doesn't necessarily mean higher quality.
vocab.tr: 更高的价格并不一定意味着更高的质量。

vocab.ex: The company's technology is severely outdated and needs an upgrade.
vocab.tr: 公司的技术严重过时，需要升级。

vocab.ex: Waiting in that long line was a complete waste of time.
vocab.tr: 在那么长的队伍里等待完全是浪费时间。

vocab.ex: I don't enjoy big parties, but that's just me.
vocab.tr: 我不喜欢大型派对，但这只是我个人的看法。

paras.en: So you’re like, “Maddie, college—ew. Boot camps—ew. What do I do then?” Well, I’ll show you.
paras.cn: 所以你可能会想：“麦迪，大学——恶心。训练营——恶心。那我该怎么办？” 嗯，我来告诉你。

vocab.ex: Ew, there's a spider in my shoe!
vocab.tr: 恶心，我鞋里有只蜘蛛！

paras.en: This is the cybersecurity roadmap. It’s on roadmap.sh—just look up “cybersecurity roadmap” in your browser and you’ll see it. Literally following this exactly and checking things off one by one is going to get you really far, in my opinion. This has the same concepts as Security+, but laid out visually.
paras.cn: 这就是网络安全路线图。它在roadmap.sh上——只要在你的浏览器里查一下“cybersecurity roadmap”你就能看到。在我看来，完全精确地遵循这个路线图，并逐一完成事项，会让你走得很远。这包含了和Security+相同的概念，但是是可视化地呈现出来的。

vocab.ex: The company presented its product roadmap for the next five years.
vocab.tr: 该公司展示了其未来五年的产品路线图。

vocab.ex: If you don't know the word, you should look it up in a dictionary.
vocab.tr: 如果你不认识这个词，你应该在字典里查一下。

vocab.ex: It's so satisfying to check things off your to-do list.
vocab.tr: 在待办事项清单上勾掉项目是件非常令人满足的事。

vocab.ex: The teacher called the students' names one by one.
vocab.tr: 老师逐一地叫了学生们的名字。

vocab.mean: 让你走得远；让你取得很大成功
vocab.ex: Hard work and a positive attitude will get you far in life.
vocab.tr: 努力工作和积极的态度会让你在生活中走得很远。

vocab.ex: The report lays out the company's financial performance in detail.
vocab.tr: 该报告详细地呈现了公司的财务表现。

vocab.ex: The data was presented visually using charts and graphs.
vocab.tr: 数据通过图表被可视化地呈现出来。

paras.en: If you want to delay getting Security+, or just want to dip your toe in, I’d definitely recommend following this roadmap. Not to say you don’t need Security+—you do, for HR and to get past non-technical hiring managers—but literally all of this is awesome foundation.
paras.cn: 如果你想延迟考取Security+，或者只是想浅尝辄止，我绝对推荐遵循这个路线图。不是说你不需要Security+——你需要，为了应付人力资源和通过非技术背景的招聘经理——但说真的，所有这些都是极好的基础。

vocab.ex: We had to delay our trip due to bad weather.
vocab.tr: 由于天气不好，我们不得不延迟我们的旅行。

vocab.ex: He decided to dip his toe in the stock market by investing a small amount of money.
vocab.tr: 他决定通过投资少量资金来初步尝试一下股市。

vocab.ex: He's a bit quiet, not to say he's unfriendly.
vocab.tr: 他有点安静，但不是说他不友好。

vocab.ex: You need a special keycard to get past this security door.
vocab.tr: 你需要一张特殊的钥匙卡才能通过这扇安全门。

vocab.ex: This course provides a solid foundation in mathematics.
vocab.tr: 这门课程为数学打下了坚实的基础。

paras.en: So we have: - Cybersecurity fundamental IT skills - Computer hardware components - Connection types and their functions - OS-independent troubleshooting - Understand basics of popular suites - Basics of computer networking (which I said is very important)
paras.cn: 所以我们有：- 网络安全基础IT技能 - 计算机硬件组件 - 连接类型及其功能 - 独立于操作系统的故障排除 - 理解流行套件的基础知识 - 计算机网络基础（我说过这个非常重要）

vocab.ex: Understanding the fundamental principles is crucial for mastering any subject.
vocab.tr: 理解基本原理对于掌握任何学科都至关重要。

vocab.ex: He learned how to assemble all the different components of the computer.
vocab.tr: 他学会了如何组装电脑的所有不同组件。

vocab.ex: The new software is OS-independent and can run on both Windows and MacOS.
vocab.tr: 这款新软件独立于操作系统，可以在Windows和MacOS上运行。

vocab.ex: He's very good at troubleshooting computer problems.
vocab.tr: 他非常擅长排除电脑故障。

vocab.ex: He installed the new office suite on his computer.
vocab.tr: 他在电脑上安装了新的办公套件。

paras.en: And then for networking, we have: - Basics of subnetting (very important—I didn’t know subnetting myself, even with a cybersecurity degree, which shows how weird college is) - Public vs. private IP addresses - Local hosts, subnet mask, default gateway, CIDR - Understanding terminology: DHCP, DNS, IP, NAT, VLAN, router vs. switch - Really good to know: network topologies, how packets are made, how each layer stacks upon itself within the OSI model
paras.cn: 然后是网络方面，我们有：- 子网划分基础（非常重要——我自己都不懂子网划分，即使有网络安全学位，这显示了大学有多奇怪）- 公网 vs. 私网IP地址 - 本地主机、子网掩码、默认网关、CIDR - 理解术语：DHCP、DNS、IP、NAT、VLAN、路由器 vs. 交换机 - 最好了解：网络拓扑、数据包如何生成、OSI模型中每一层如何相互堆叠

vocab.ex: Subnetting is an essential skill for any network administrator.
vocab.tr: 子网划分是任何网络管理员的必备技能。

vocab.ex: Every device connected to the internet has a unique IP address.
vocab.tr: 每个连接到互联网的设备都有一个唯一的IP地址。

vocab.ex: The default gateway is the router that connects your local network to the internet.
vocab.tr: 默认网关是连接你本地网络到互联网的路由器。

vocab.ex: It's important to understand the basic terminology of any new field you study.
vocab.tr: 理解你所学的任何新领域的基本术语是很重要的。

vocab.ex: A star network topology connects all devices to a central hub.
vocab.tr: 星型网络拓扑将所有设备连接到一个中心集线器。

vocab.ex: Information is sent over the internet in small units called packets.
vocab.tr: 信息通过互联网以称为数据包的小单位发送。

vocab.mean: OSI模型（开放系统互连模型）
vocab.ex: The OSI model is a conceptual framework that standardizes the functions of a telecommunication system.
vocab.tr: OSI模型是一个将电信系统功能标准化的概念框架。

paras.en: The OSI model comes in extremely clutch when you’re trying to understand all these concepts. And it’s actually down below under “Understanding the OSI Model”—yes, very important. Over here we have troubleshooting tools—very important—like `ipconfig`, `ping`, `dig`. That stuff is really important in troubleshooting. I hope that stuff really comes in clutch—not to say “clutch” again, that’s kind of cringe—but it does.
paras.cn: 当你想理解所有这些概念时，OSI模型会非常管用。它实际上就在下面的“理解OSI模型”部分——是的，非常重要。这边我们有故障排除工具——非常重要——比如`ipconfig`、`ping`、`dig`。那些东西在故障排除中非常重要。我希望那些东西真的能派上大用场——不想再说“管用”了，那有点尬——但它确实管用。

vocab.ex: My backup battery really came in clutch when my phone died.
vocab.tr: 我手机没电时，我的备用电池真的在关键时刻派上了用场。

vocab.ex: You'll find the contact information down below in the description box.
vocab.tr: 你可以在下面的描述框里找到联系信息。

vocab.ex: He's very good at troubleshooting computer problems.
vocab.tr: 他非常擅长排除电脑故障。

vocab.ex: His attempt at stand-up comedy was so bad it was cringe.
vocab.tr: 他的单口喜剧表演太差了，简直令人尴尬。

paras.en: And then: - Authentication methodologies: Kerberos, LDAP, SSO, RADIUS (also really important). Once you keep scrolling down, you get into more security-focused stuff: - DDoS, Evil Twin, Deauth attacks, SIEM, Yara rules, Kali, Kill Chain, Diamond Model—things of that nature.
paras.cn: 然后是：- 身份验证方法论：Kerberos、LDAP、SSO、RADIUS（也非常重要）。一旦你继续向下滚动，你就会进入更侧重于安全的东西：- DDoS、邪恶双胞胎、Deauth攻击、SIEM、Yara规则、Kali、杀伤链、钻石模型——诸如此类的东西。

vocab.ex: Two-factor authentication adds an extra layer of security to your account.
vocab.tr: 双因素认证为你的账户增加了一层额外的安全保障。

vocab.ex: The research paper clearly explains the methodology used in the study.
vocab.tr: 该研究论文清楚地解释了研究中使用的方法论。

vocab.ex: The conversation started with small talk, but then we got into deeper topics.
vocab.tr: 对话以闲聊开始，但后来我们进入了更深层次的话题。

vocab.ex: The company is hiring for a new, security-focused software development role.
vocab.tr: 该公司正在招聘一个新的、侧重于安全的软件开发职位。

vocab.ex: The museum displays old tools, pottery, and other things of that nature.
vocab.tr: 博物馆展出古老的工具、陶器和诸如此类的其他东西。

paras.en: So I’d just say, go through literally all of this. Cloud concepts—super good: S3, Dropbox, Google Drive, OneDrive, AWS, GCP, Azure. I’d just go through this and check everything off as you’re learning.
paras.cn: 所以我只想说，把所有这些都过一遍。云概念——超级棒：S3、Dropbox、Google Drive、OneDrive、AWS、GCP、Azure。我建议你把这个过一遍，边学边把每样东西都勾掉。

vocab.ex: Let's go through the checklist one more time to make sure we haven't forgotten anything.
vocab.tr: 我们再把清单过一遍，确保没有忘记任何东西。

vocab.ex: The concept of infinity can be difficult to grasp.
vocab.tr: 无穷大的概念可能很难理解。

vocab.ex: It's so satisfying to check off items on your to-do list.
vocab.tr: 在待办事项清单上勾掉项目是件非常令人满足的事。

paras.en: You can go to roadmap.sh and click it—it takes you to a bunch of roadmaps for roles, which is very useful: AI engineer, software architect, game developer, technical writer… and then skill-based roadmaps. Yeah, I’d definitely recommend this.
paras.cn: 你可以去roadmap.sh然后点击它——它会带你到一大堆针对不同角色的路线图，这非常有用：AI工程师、软件架构师、游戏开发者、技术文档撰写人……然后还有基于技能的路线图。是的，我绝对推荐这个。

vocab.ex: I have a bunch of emails to answer before I can leave.
vocab.tr: 我走之前有一大堆邮件要回复。

vocab.ex: She was recently promoted to a leadership role in the company.
vocab.tr: 她最近被提升到公司的一个领导职位。

vocab.ex: As a software architect, he designs the overall structure of the application.
vocab.tr: 作为一名软件架构师，他设计应用程序的整体结构。

vocab.ex: The company is moving towards a more skill-based hiring process.
vocab.tr: 该公司正转向一个更基于技能的招聘流程。

paras.en: Now for certifications, I’d highly recommend Security+ as your base. Definitely get Security+. Go back and get Network+ if you want, but if you can actually prove you know the foundational stuff of networking and OSs, then I think you’re pretty much golden as long as you have Security+.
paras.cn: 现在说到证书，我强烈推荐Security+作为你的基础。一定要考到Security+。如果你想，可以回头去考Network+，但如果你能真正证明你懂网络和操作系统的基础知识，那么我认为只要你有了Security+，你就基本稳了。

vocab.ex: He earned a certification in project management.
vocab.tr: 他获得了项目管理方面的认证。

vocab.ex: A strong understanding of the basics provides a good base for advanced learning.
vocab.tr: 对基础知识的扎实理解为高级学习提供了良好的基础。

vocab.ex: You need to prove your identity with a valid ID card.
vocab.tr: 你需要用有效的身份证件来证明你的身份。

vocab.ex: This course covers the foundational concepts of programming.
vocab.tr: 这门课程涵盖了编程的基础概念。

vocab.ex: I'm pretty much done with my work for today.
vocab.tr: 我今天的活儿差不多干完了。

vocab.ex: Once you pass this final exam, you're golden for graduation.
vocab.tr: 一旦你通过了这场期末考试，你毕业就稳了。

vocab.ex: You can go to the party, as long as you finish your homework first.
vocab.tr: 你可以去派对，只要你先完成作业。

paras.en: One thing I believe people in the cybersecurity industry and community really don’t speak up enough about is how much you need to know M365 administration. At least in my experience—not to burst your bubble—but you’ll probably have to do help desk before getting into cybersecurity. Cybersecurity is not an entry-level job, contrary to what everyone tells you.
paras.cn: 我认为网络安全行业和社区的人们有一件事说得不够多，那就是你需要多么了解M365管理。至少在我的经验里是这样——不是要给你泼冷水——但在进入网络安全领域之前，你可能得先做服务台。与大家告诉你的相反，网络安全不是一个入门级的工作。

vocab.ex: It's important to speak up about issues you care about.
vocab.tr: 公开谈论你关心的问题是很重要的。

vocab.ex: Network administration requires a lot of technical skill.
vocab.tr: 网络管理需要大量的技术技能。

vocab.mean: 给你泼冷水；打破你的幻想
vocab.ex: I hate to burst your bubble, but Santa Claus isn't real.
vocab.tr: 我不想给你泼冷水，但圣诞老人不是真的。

vocab.ex: He's looking for an entry-level job in the tech industry.
vocab.tr: 他正在科技行业寻找一份入门级的工作。

vocab.ex: Contrary to popular belief, tomatoes are actually fruits.
vocab.tr: 与普遍看法相反，西红柿其实是水果。

paras.en: So M365 administration: everyone has M365, everyone needs to provision users, groups, distribution lists, reset passwords, investigate phishing emails. Literally, it’s all very, very boring, but it’s a very good way to get your foot in the door.
paras.cn: 所以M365管理：每个人都有M365，每个人都需要配置用户、组、分发列表、重置密码、调查网络钓鱼邮件。说真的，这一切都非常非常无聊，但这是你踏入这个行业的一个非常好的方式。

vocab.ex: The IT department needs to provision a new virtual machine for the project.
vocab.tr: IT部门需要为该项目配置一台新的虚拟机。

vocab.ex: Please add the new employee to the marketing distribution list.
vocab.tr: 请将新员工添加到市场营销分发列表中。

vocab.ex: The police are investigating the cause of the accident.
vocab.tr: 警方正在调查事故原因。

vocab.ex: Never click on suspicious links in emails; it could be a phishing attempt.
vocab.tr: 切勿点击邮件中的可疑链接，那可能是网络钓鱼企图。

vocab.word: get your foot in the door
vocab.mean: （在公司或行业中）获得初步的立足点；迈出第一步
vocab.ex: An internship is a great way to get your foot in the door of a competitive industry.
vocab.tr: 实习是在一个竞争激烈的行业中迈出第一步的好方法。
match: get your foot in the door

paras.en: I’d highly recommend getting a Microsoft certification—like an Azure certification or something. This one’s good—I haven’t taken it myself because I’ve done M365 administration a lot, so I have the work experience. But if you don’t, or even if you do and just want a cert, the Microsoft 365 Administrator exam seems like something you’d take if you need to prove your M365 admin skills.
paras.cn: 我强烈推荐考一个微软认证——比如Azure认证之类的。这个就很好——我自己没考过，因为我已经做过很多M365管理了，所以我有工作经验。但如果你没有，或者即使你有但只是想要个证书，微软365管理员考试似乎就是你需要考的东西，如果你需要证明你的M365管理技能的话。

vocab.ex: I highly recommend this book; it's one of the best I've ever read.
vocab.tr: 我强烈推荐这本书；它是我读过的最好的书之一。

vocab.ex: He just got a new cert in cloud computing.
vocab.tr: 他刚拿到了一个云计算方面的新证书。

vocab.ex: He works in network admin for a large company.
vocab.tr: 他在一家大公司从事网络管理工作。

paras.en: If anyone else has better certification suggestions, put them in the comments. And maybe you’re thinking, “Maddie, why haven’t you mentioned A+?” Well, it’s vendor-agnostic, and everyone uses Microsoft—at least in my experience. I haven’t taken A+. My old boss suggested I take A+ while I was analyzing logs, manually threat hunting, and doing sysadmin work, and I was like, “Why would I take that if I’m already doing the work?”
paras.cn: 如果其他人有更好的证书建议，请把它们写在评论里。也许你在想：“麦迪，你为什么没提A+？” 嗯，它是厂商中立的，而每个人都在用微软——至少在我的经验里是这样。我没考过A+。我以前的老板在我分析日志、手动进行威胁搜寻和做系统管理工作时建议我考A+，我当时就想：“如果我已经在了做这些工作，我为什么还要考那个？”

vocab.ex: Do you have any suggestions for a good place to eat?
vocab.tr: 你有什么好吃的地方推荐吗？

vocab.mean: 厂商中立的（不依赖于特定供应商的技术）
vocab.ex: The certification is vendor-agnostic, which makes it valuable across many different systems.
vocab.tr: 该认证是厂商中立的，这使得它在许多不同系统中都很有价值。

vocab.ex: Proactive threat hunting is crucial for identifying advanced cyber attacks.
vocab.tr: 主动的威胁搜寻对于识别高级网络攻击至关重要。

vocab.ex: If you can't log in, you should contact the sysadmin.
vocab.tr: 如果你无法登录，你应该联系系统管理员。

paras.en: So yeah—vendor-agnostic. You can go through Professor Messer—you all should know that man by now, he’s a G. He has videos on A+, Security+, Network+, things like that. So if you want to go through A+, watch his videos, take notes—but I wouldn’t suggest wasting your money on the A+. My personal opinion.
paras.cn: 所以，是的——厂商中立。你可以去看Messer教授的视频——你们现在都应该知道那个人了，他是个大佬。他有关于A+、Security+、Network+之类的视频。所以如果你想学A+，看他的视频，做笔记——但我不会建议你在A+上浪费钱。我个人意见。

vocab.ex: Let's go through the checklist one more time.
vocab.tr: 我们再把清单过一遍。

vocab.ex: You should know the rules by now; you've been here long enough.
vocab.tr: 你到现在应该知道规则了；你已经在这里待了足够长的时间。

vocab.mean: （俚语）大佬； gangster (黑帮分子) 的缩写
vocab.ex: He's a true G in the music industry, respected by everyone.
vocab.tr: 他是音乐界的真大佬，受到所有人的尊重。

vocab.ex: It's a good idea to take notes during the lecture.
vocab.tr: 在讲座期间做笔记是个好主意。

paras.en: Another platform I’d suggest learning on is TryHackMe. TryHackMe is awesome—they’ve sponsored me before; this one isn’t sponsored, I’m just shouting them out because they’re cool. Cybersecurity training platform—you can go through lessons, do CTFs (which stand for Capture the Flag), really hone your cybersecurity skills, and you get these little certifications to prove you’ve completed a learning path. It’s cool.
paras.cn: 另一个我建议的学习平台是TryHackMe。TryHackMe超棒——他们以前赞助过我；这次没有赞助，我只是给他们打个广告，因为他们很酷。一个网络安全培训平台——你可以上课、做CTF（夺旗赛的缩写）、真正磨练你的网络安全技能，而且你还能得到这些小证书来证明你完成了一个学习路径。很酷。

vocab.ex: The local company agreed to sponsor our soccer team.
vocab.tr: 当地公司同意赞助我们的足球队。

vocab.ex: I want to give a quick shout out to my parents for all their support.
vocab.tr: 我想简单地向我的父母致意，感谢他们所有的支持。

vocab.mean: 夺旗赛（一种网络安全竞赛）
vocab.ex: He improved his hacking skills by participating in online CTF competitions.
vocab.tr: 他通过参加在线CTF竞赛提高了他的黑客技能。

vocab.ex: She practiced every day to hone her skills as a pianist.
vocab.tr: 她每天练习，以磨练她作为钢琴家的技巧。

vocab.ex: The online course offers a structured learning path for beginners.
vocab.tr: 该在线课程为初学者提供了一个结构化的学习路径。

paras.en: There’s also Hack The Box—a very good cybersecurity training platform as well, kind of similar to TryHackMe, but a little more advanced in the CTF and learning department. I’d definitely do TryHackMe for beginners just starting out into intermediate, then transition over to Hack The Box once you get the hang of things.
paras.cn: 还有Hack The Box——也是一个非常好的网络安全培训平台，有点像TryHackMe，但在CTF和学习部门方面更高级一些。我绝对会推荐初学者刚开始向中级过渡时用TryHackMe，一旦你掌握了窍门，再转到Hack The Box。

vocab.ex: This is an advanced course for students who have already mastered the basics.
vocab.tr: 这是一门为已经掌握了基础知识的学生设计的高级课程。

vocab.ex: He's not very skilled in the creativity department.
vocab.tr: 他在创造力方面不太擅长。

vocab.ex: When you're just starting out in your career, it's important to be willing to learn.
vocab.tr: 当你刚开始你的职业生涯时，愿意学习是很重要的。

vocab.ex: This class is for students at an intermediate level of English.
vocab.tr: 这个班是为中级英语水平的学生开设的。

vocab.ex: After mastering the basics, you can transition over to more advanced topics.
vocab.tr: 掌握了基础知识后，你就可以过渡到更高级的主题了。

vocab.ex: It took me a while, but I finally got the hang of using the new software.
vocab.tr: 花了我一点时间，但我最终还是掌握了使用新软件的窍门。

paras.en: I do have a link—I’ll put it in the description—to sign up for Hack The Box. If you use my link and sign up and subscribe to one of the tiers, I do get a little kickback. So if you were going to sign up anyway, use my link—I’d really appreciate it.
paras.cn: 我确实有一个链接——我会把它放在描述里——用于注册Hack The Box。如果你用我的链接注册并订阅了其中一个等级，我确实能得到一点回扣。所以如果你反正都要注册，就用我的链接吧——我会非常感激的。

vocab.ex: You can find all the product links in the video description below.
vocab.tr: 你可以在下方视频描述区找到所有产品链接。

vocab.ex: You need to sign up for an account to use the service.
vocab.tr: 你需要注册一个账户才能使用该服务。

vocab.ex: The streaming service offers several subscription tiers with different features.
vocab.tr: 该流媒体服务提供几种具有不同功能的订阅等级。

vocab.ex: The salesperson received a kickback for every new client he brought in.
vocab.tr: 那位销售员每带来一个新客户都能收到一笔回扣。

vocab.ex: I know it's late, but I'm going to finish this book anyway.
vocab.tr: 我知道很晚了，但我反正要读完这本书。

vocab.ex: I really appreciate all your help and support.
vocab.tr: 我真的很感激你所有的帮助和支持。

paras.en: Another thing I’d do if I was starting over: you’re learning, you’ve got the fundamentals down, you’ve got some certs, you’re doing labs, you’re taking notes—big one there: take notes of everything you do. After you have all your learnings and notes, I would post them onto LinkedIn and your own blog. I was posting what I was learning on LinkedIn—things I was learning in cybersecurity, Hack The Box, TryHackMe badges, certifications I got. I was literally posting anything and everything cybersecurity, and people started following along for the journey.
paras.cn: 如果我重新开始，我还会做另一件事：你在学习，你掌握了基础，你拿了些证书，你在做实验，你在做笔记——这点很重要：把你做的每件事都记下来。在你有了所有学到的东西和笔记之后，我会把它们发布到领英和你自己的博客上。我当时就在领英上发布我正在学的东西——我在网络安全、Hack The Box、TryHackMe徽章、我获得的证书中学到的东西。我简直是在发布任何和所有关于网络安全的东西，人们开始关注我的这段旅程。

vocab.ex: Once you get the basics down, the rest will be much easier.
vocab.tr: 一旦你掌握了基础，剩下的就会容易得多。

vocab.ex: Remember to be on time. That's a big one for this new boss.
vocab.tr: 记住要准时。这对新老板来说是重要的一点。

vocab.ex: After completing the course, he earned a digital badge for his profile.
vocab.tr: 完成课程后，他为自己的个人资料赢得了一枚数字徽章。

vocab.ex: The museum has anything and everything related to local history.
vocab.tr: 该博物馆拥有任何及所有与当地历史相关的东西。

vocab.ex: Thousands of fans followed along as he documented his journey on social media.
vocab.tr: 成千上万的粉丝关注着他在社交媒体上记录的旅程。

paras.en: Long story short—I have a longer video on my channel, I’ll link it in the description if you want the full story—but I got the attention of a CEO, and he was like, “Hey, I love your blog, I love your write-ups, your TTPs, your projects, your home lab. Do you want to interview for this position?” And that’s actually how I got my first cybersecurity job. I didn’t apply; I didn’t go through the standard process. I was found on social media.
paras.cn: 长话短说——我频道里有个更长的视频，如果你想知道完整故事，我会把链接放在描述里——但我引起了一位CEO的注意，他当时就说：“嘿，我喜欢你的博客，我喜欢你的文章、你的TTP、你的项目、你的家庭实验室。你想面试这个职位吗？” 我实际上就是这样得到我的第一份网络安全工作的。我没有申请；我没有走标准流程。我是在社交媒体上被发现的。

vocab.ex: We had a lot of issues, but long story short, we made it.
vocab.tr: 我们遇到了很多问题，但长话短说，我们成功了。

vocab.ex: He published a detailed write-up of his research findings on his blog.
vocab.tr: 他在博客上发表了一份关于他研究发现的详细报告。

vocab.mean: 战术、技术和程序（网络安全术语）
vocab.ex: Analyzing the attacker's TTPs can help predict future threats.
vocab.tr: 分析攻击者的TTP有助于预测未来的威胁。

vocab.ex: He built a small home lab to practice his cybersecurity skills.
vocab.tr: 他建了一个小型的家庭实验室来练习他的网络安全技能。

vocab.ex: Applicants must go through the standard process of submitting a resume and attending an interview.
vocab.tr: 申请人必须经过提交简历和参加面试的标准流程。

paras.en: If you don’t post what you know, others will not know that you know it. You have to be loud. You have to be like, “Hey, I know this stuff, I’m doing this stuff, look at what I’m learning—isn’t this so cool? You can learn it too—here’s the write-up, here’s the walkthrough.” Knowledge share, and you’ll garner the attention of recruiters, hiring managers, CEOs. Like, everyone and their mother is—unfortunately—on LinkedIn, so that’s where you have to be posting your content.
paras.cn: 如果你不把你所知道的发布出来，别人就不会知道你知道它。你必须大声说出来。你必须像是说：“嘿，我懂这些东西，我在做这些东西，看我在学什么——这不是很酷吗？你也可以学——这是文章，这是演练。” 知识分享，你就会吸引招聘人员、招聘经理、CEO的注意。就像，每个人和他妈的都在——不幸的是——在领英上，所以你必须在那里发布你的内容。

vocab.ex: To get noticed in a crowded market, your brand has to be loud.
vocab.tr: 要在拥挤的市场中被注意到，你的品牌必须高调。

vocab.ex: He posted a video walkthrough of the difficult game level on YouTube.
vocab.tr: 他在YouTube上发布了一个关于那个困难游戏关卡的视频攻略。

vocab.ex: Her new book has garnered a lot of positive reviews.
vocab.tr: 她的新书获得了很多好评。

vocab.ex: A recruiter from a top tech company contacted him on LinkedIn.
vocab.tr: 一位顶尖科技公司的招聘人员在领英上联系了他。

vocab.ex: It seemed like everyone and their mother was at the concert last night.
vocab.tr: 昨晚的音乐会好像所有人都去了。

paras.en: Having a blog also helps. I actually started posting on Medium—it’s a write-up blog hosting platform. It’s free to sign up, create an account, and start posting your CTF write-ups, your projects, anything. Post about it on LinkedIn: “Hey, here’s this project, here’s the link to my blog,” things like that.
paras.cn: 拥有一个博客也有帮助。我实际上是在Medium上开始发布的——它是一个文章博客托管平台。注册、创建账户，然后开始发布你的CTF文章、你的项目，任何东西，都是免费的。在领英上发帖宣传：“嘿，这是这个项目，这是我博客的链接，”诸如此类。

vocab.ex: He chose a reliable hosting platform for his new website.
vocab.tr: 他为他的新网站选择了一个可靠的托管平台。

vocab.ex: You need to sign up for an account to use the service.
vocab.tr: 你需要注册一个账户才能使用该服务。

vocab.ex: He improved his hacking skills by participating in online CTF competitions.
vocab.tr: 他通过参加在线CTF竞赛提高了他的黑客技能。

vocab.ex: I enjoy outdoor activities like hiking, camping, and things like that.
vocab.tr: 我喜欢户外活动，比如徒步、露营之类的。

paras.en: Another thing you need to do—and what I would do if I could start all over again—is network more. Network online, on Discord, at conferences—literally network your ass off. Network like your job depends on it, because it literally does. I have never gotten a single job by applying. It’s always been through either online networking, social media, referrals, or in-person networking. Literally, it’s all been through human connection. So that is a must when trying to get a job in cybersecurity.
paras.cn: 你需要做的另一件事——也是如果我能重新来过我会做的事——就是多社交。在线上、在Discord上、在会议上社交——真的要拼了命地去社交。像你的工作取决于它一样去社交，因为它真的取决于此。我从来没有通过申请得到过任何一份工作。总是通过线上社交、社交媒体、推荐，或线下社交。真的，全都通过人际关系。所以当你想在网络安全领域找到工作时，这是必须的。

vocab.ex: It's important to network with people in your industry.
vocab.tr: 与你行业内的人建立人脉很重要。

vocab.ex: To build his business, he had to network his ass off at every industry event.
vocab.tr: 为了建立他的生意，他不得不在每个行业活动中拼了命地社交。

vocab.ex: Our picnic plan will depend on the weather.
vocab.tr: 我们的野餐计划将取决于天气。

vocab.ex: He got the job through a referral from a former colleague.
vocab.tr: 他通过一位前同事的推荐得到了这份工作。

vocab.ex: After a year of online meetings, they finally had an in-person conference.
vocab.tr: 经过一年的在线会议，他们终于举行了一场线下会议。

vocab.mean: 人际关系；人与人之间的联系
vocab.ex: In a world of technology, she valued genuine human connection.
vocab.tr: 在科技的世界里，她珍视真诚的人际联系。

vocab.ex: If you visit Paris, seeing the Eiffel Tower is a must.
vocab.tr: 如果你去巴黎，看埃菲尔铁塔是必须的。

paras.en: Go to DEF CON—that’s a big one—or your local BSides. Literally, any way you can get out, network with people, talk about passion, make connections. That’s going to take you farther than any resume.
paras.cn: 去DEF CON——那是个大活动——或者你本地的BSides。真的，任何你能走出去的方式，和人们社交，谈论热情，建立联系。那会比任何简历都让你走得更远。

vocab.mean: 一个大的/重要的（活动等）
vocab.ex: The final exam is coming up; that's the big one.
vocab.tr: 期末考试要来了，那可是个大头。

vocab.ex: We prefer to support local businesses.
vocab.tr: 我们更愿意支持本地企业。

vocab.ex: You've been inside all day; you need to get out and get some fresh air.
vocab.tr: 你在室内待了一整天了，你需要出去呼吸点新鲜空气。

vocab.ex: She has a real passion for painting.
vocab.tr: 她对绘画有真正的热情。

vocab.ex: A good attitude will take you farther in life than just talent alone.
vocab.tr: 良好的态度会比单有才能让你在生活中走得更远。

vocab.ex: He updated his resume before applying for the new job.
vocab.tr: 在申请新工作前，他更新了他的简历。

paras.en: If I had to start all over in cybersecurity from scratch, I would: - Post everything I was doing - Focus more on actual skills that will help me get into cybersecurity - Not focus too much on pen testing or red teaming—that’s not very practical when you’re trying to get in - Focus more on help desk and M365 administration, hardening Windows security, AD security—things like that—to prove you know security - Be kind of like a sysadmin, then work your way up to a more cybersecurity-focused role - And networking—again, very important. Network as much as possible. Put yourself out there, because you never know who might see your stuff.
paras.cn: 如果我必须从零开始重新学习网络安全，我会：- 发布我做的所有事情 - 更专注于能帮我进入网络安全领域的实际技能 - 不太专注于渗透测试或红队——当你试图入行时那不太实际 - 更专注于服务台和M365管理、加固Windows安全、AD安全——诸如此类——来证明你懂安全 - 有点像个系统管理员，然后逐步晋升到更侧重于网络安全的职位 - 还有社交——再次强调，非常重要。尽可能多地社交。把自己展示出去，因为你永远不知道谁会看到你的东西。

vocab.ex: I made a mistake on the last step, so I have to start all over again.
vocab.tr: 我在最后一步上犯了个错，所以我得重新来过。

vocab.ex: The company hired a specialist to conduct regular pen testing on their systems.
vocab.tr: 公司雇佣了一位专家对他们的系统进行定期的渗透测试。

vocab.ex: Red teaming involves simulating an attack to test an organization's defenses.
vocab.tr: 红队演练包括模拟一次攻击来测试一个组织的防御能力。

vocab.ex: She gave me some practical advice on how to save money.
vocab.tr: 她给了我一些关于如何省钱的实用建议。

vocab.ex: System hardening is the process of securing a system by reducing its surface of vulnerability.
vocab.tr: 系统加固是通过减少其漏洞表面来保护系统的过程。

vocab.ex: She started as an intern and worked her way up to become the CEO.
vocab.tr: 她从实习生做起，一步步晋升为CEO。

vocab.ex: If you want to be a successful artist, you have to put yourself out there and show your work.
vocab.tr: 如果你想成为一个成功的艺术家，你必须走出去，展示你的作品。

vocab.mean: 你永远不知道（世事难料）
vocab.ex: You should apply for the job; you never know, you might get it!
vocab.tr: 你应该申请那份工作；世事难料，说不定你就得到了呢！

paras.en: Anyway, that is it for the video. Make sure to like, subscribe, punch all the buttons in the face, and I will see you in the next one.
paras.cn: 总之，本期视频就到这里。确保点赞、订阅、把所有按钮都给捶一遍，我们下个视频见。

vocab.ex: That is it for today's lesson. Class dismissed.
vocab.tr: 今天的课就到这里。下课。

vocab.ex: He was so frustrated with the vending machine that he wanted to punch it in the face.
vocab.tr: 他对那台自动售货机感到非常沮沮丧，很想给它一拳。
match: punch all the buttons in the face

vocab.word: see you in the next one
vocab.ex: Thanks for watching, and I'll see you in the next one.
vocab.tr: 感谢收看，我们下个视频见。
match: see you in the next one

title: What Social Media Replaced in Our Lives

paras.en: Everyone talks about how social media waste time, but no one actually talks about what it replaced in our lives. When I quit social media, I discovered something shocking. I wasn't just addicted to scrolling. I was using it to feel emotional needs I didn't even know existed.
paras.cn: 每个人都在谈论社交媒体如何浪费时间，但没有人真正谈论它在我们生活中取代了什么。当我戒掉社交媒体时，我发现了一些令人震惊的事情。我不仅仅是对刷手机上瘾。我是在用它来满足我甚至不知道存在的精神需求。

vocab.ex: He tends to waste time watching silly videos online.
vocab.tr: 他总是浪费时间在网上看傻乎乎的视频。

vocab.ex: Smartphones have replaced many traditional devices like cameras and music players.
vocab.tr: 智能手机已经取代了像相机和音乐播放器这样的许多传统设备。

vocab.ex: She is completely addicted to that new mobile game.
vocab.tr: 她对那个新手机游戏完全上瘾了。

vocab.ex: Mindless scrolling before bed can negatively affect your sleep.
vocab.tr: 睡前无意识地刷手机会对你的睡眠产生负面影响。

vocab.ex: A healthy relationship should meet the emotional needs of both partners.
vocab.tr: 一段健康的关系应该满足双方的精神需求。

paras.en: If you've seen my previous videos, you know that I've been off social media for 5 years now, but it took me years to understand that deleting apps wasn't enough. Social media wasn't just taking my time. It was acting as a band-aid for deeper needs.
paras.cn: 如果你看过我以前的视频，你就会知道我已经戒掉社交媒体5年了，但我花了好几年才明白，删除应用程序是不够的。社交媒体不仅仅是在占用我的时间。它是在为更深层次的需求充当创可贴。

vocab.ex: Please refer to the notes from the previous meeting.
vocab.tr: 请参考上次会议的笔记。

vocab.ex: He's trying to be off caffeine for a month to see if he feels better.
vocab.tr: 他正试图戒掉咖啡因一个月，看看是否感觉会好些。

vocab.mean: 创可贴（比喻治标不治本的临时解决办法）
vocab.ex: Just apologizing is a band-aid; you need to address the root of the problem.
vocab.tr: 仅仅道歉是治标不治本的；你需要解决问题的根源。

paras.en: I used to think that having hundreds of people wish me happy birthday meant that I had stronger connections. Social media wasn't just taking my time. It was replacing real intimacy with shallow connections. It gave me just enough social interactions to feel less lonely, but not enough to actually fulfill my need for genuine connection.
paras.cn: 我过去常常认为，有几百个人祝我生日快乐就意味着我有更强的人际关系。社交媒体不仅仅是在占用我的时间。它是在用肤浅的联系取代真正的亲密关系。它给了我恰到好处的社交互动，让我感觉不那么孤单，但又不足以真正满足我对真诚联系的需求。

vocab.ex: He made many valuable connections at the business conference.
vocab.tr: 他在商务会议上建立了许多宝贵的人脉。

vocab.ex: True friendship is built on trust and emotional intimacy.
vocab.tr: 真正的友谊建立在信任和情感的亲密关系之上。

vocab.ex: Their conversation was very shallow, only about celebrities and shopping.
vocab.tr: 他们的谈话非常肤浅，只涉及名人和购物。

vocab.ex: He hoped his new job would fulfill his need for a creative challenge.
vocab.tr: 他希望他的新工作能满足他对创造性挑战的需求。

vocab.ex: She has a genuine interest in helping others.
vocab.tr: 她对帮助他人有真诚的兴趣。

paras.en: Social media wasn't just distracting me. It was replacing my ability to validate myself. Every like was a tiny hit of external validation, teaching my brain to depend on others for my own self-worth.
paras.cn: 社交媒体不仅仅是在分散我的注意力。它是在取代我自我肯定的能力。每一个点赞都是一次微小的外部认可，教我的大脑依赖他人来获得我自己的自我价值。

vocab.ex: The loud noise from the street was distracting me from my work.
vocab.tr: 街上传来的巨大噪音让我无法专心工作。

vocab.ex: It's important to learn how to validate your own feelings without needing others' approval.
vocab.tr: 学会自我肯定感受而无需他人认可是很重要的。

vocab.mean: 一小剂（通常指带来快感的东西）
vocab.ex: For him, a morning coffee is a necessary hit of caffeine.
vocab.tr: 对他来说，早晨的咖啡是必需的一剂咖啡因。

vocab.ex: Relying too much on external validation can be damaging to your self-esteem.
vocab.tr: 过度依赖外部认可可能会损害你的自尊。

vocab.ex: Children depend on their parents for food and shelter.
vocab.tr: 孩子们依赖父母提供食物和住所。

vocab.ex: Your self-worth should not be determined by your job title or salary.
vocab.tr: 你的自我价值不应由你的职位或薪水来决定。

paras.en: Social media wasn't just entertaining me. It was replacing my ability to sit with uncomfortable emotions and process them naturally.
paras.cn: 社交媒体不仅仅是在娱乐我。它是在取代我与不舒服的情绪共处并自然地处理它们的能力。

vocab.ex: The clown's job was to entertain the children at the party.
vocab.tr: 小丑的工作是在派对上娱乐孩子们。

vocab.ex: Instead of distracting yourself, sometimes it's better to just sit with your sadness for a while.
vocab.tr: 与其分散自己的注意力，有时不如静静地与你的悲伤共处一会儿。

vocab.ex: The silence in the room became uncomfortable.
vocab.tr: 房间里的沉默变得令人不舒服。

vocab.ex: It took him a long time to process the grief of losing his friend.
vocab.tr: 他花了很长时间才处理好失去朋友的悲痛。

paras.en: But here's what really shocked me. When I quit social media, these needs didn't go away. They just became impossible to ignore, and that's when the real work began.
paras.cn: 但真正让我震惊的是这个。当我戒掉社交媒体时，这些需求并没有消失。它们只是变得无法忽视，而那才是真正功课的开始。

vocab.ex: He decided to quit smoking for his health.
vocab.tr: 为了健康，他决定戒烟。

vocab.ex: I hope this headache will go away soon.
vocab.tr: 我希望这次头痛能快点消失。

vocab.ex: The problem has become so big that it is now impossible to ignore.
vocab.tr: 问题已经变得如此之大，现在已无法忽视。

paras.en: I had to learn how to seek validation from within, because for so long, I measured my worth by the numbers of likes, shares, and comments I received. Each notification provided a fleeting moment of external validation, but ultimately left me feeling empty. But what happens when you stop relying on those external metrics? I had to learn to celebrate my achievements privately, to trust and appreciate myself without waiting for other people's approval, by building internal confidence and practicing self-reflection. I discovered that my worth isn't defined by an online audience, but by the quiet, powerful validation from within.
paras.cn: 我必须学会如何从内在寻求认可，因为在很长一段时间里，我用收到的点赞、分享和评论的数量来衡量我的价值。每一次通知都提供了一个短暂的外部认可瞬间，但最终让我感到空虚。但是，当你停止依赖那些外部指标时会发生什么呢？我必须学会私下庆祝我的成就，在没有等待他人批准的情况下信任和欣赏自己，通过建立内在自信和进行自我反思。我发现我的价值不是由在线观众定义的，而是由内在那种安静而强大的认可定义的。

vocab.ex: True self-esteem comes from learning to seek validation from within, not from others.
vocab.tr: 真正的自尊来自于学会从内在而非他人那里寻求认可。

vocab.ex: It's a mistake to measure your worth by how much money you make.
vocab.tr: 用你赚多少钱来衡量你的价值是错误的。

vocab.ex: Happiness can sometimes feel like a fleeting moment.
vocab.tr: 快乐有时感觉就像一个短暂的瞬间。

vocab.ex: He tried many different careers, but ultimately became a teacher.
vocab.tr: 他尝试了很多不同的职业，但最终成为了一名教师。

vocab.ex: You can always rely on her to be on time.
vocab.tr: 你总可以指望她会准时。

vocab.ex: Website traffic is an important metric for online businesses.
vocab.tr: 网站流量是在线业务的一个重要指标。

vocab.ex: Graduating from college was a huge achievement for him.
vocab.tr: 大学毕业对他来说是一项巨大的成就。

vocab.ex: He was always seeking his father's approval.
vocab.tr: 他总是在寻求他父亲的认可。

vocab.ex: Journaling can be a useful tool for self-reflection.
vocab.tr: 写日记可以成为自我反思的有用工具。

paras.en: Seeking validation from within is only one piece of the puzzle. The second piece of the puzzle is knowing how to process your emotions. I used to use my phone as an escape, a way to distract myself from uncomfortable emotions like boredom, anxiety, but that wasn't processing those emotions. It was just numbing them.
paras.cn: 从内在寻求认可只是拼图的一块。拼图的第二块是知道如何处理你的情绪。我过去常常用我的手机作为一种逃避，一种分散自己注意力、不去感受像无聊、焦虑等不舒服情绪的方式，但那不是在处理那些情绪。那只是在麻痹它们。

vocab.mean: 谜题的一块（指问题的一部分）
vocab.ex: The new evidence was the final piece of the puzzle that solved the case.
vocab.tr: 新的证据是解开此案的最后一块拼图。

vocab.ex: For him, reading books is an escape from the stress of daily life.
vocab.tr: 对他来说，读书是一种逃避日常生活压力的方式。

vocab.ex: He started a new hobby to escape the boredom of his routine.
vocab.tr: 他开始了一个新爱好以摆脱他日常的无聊。

vocab.ex: He suffers from anxiety before big exams.
vocab.tr: 他在大考前会感到焦虑。

vocab.ex: The cold wind began to numb his fingers.
vocab.tr: 寒风开始使他的手指麻木。

paras.en: When I finally put the phone down, I was forced to confront what I was really feeling. Things like journaling, meditating, and talking to loved ones helped me with the discomfort and anxiety I was feeling. Having the space and time away from social media made me discover the biggest lesson, which was how to regulate my emotions without using social media. And that was key.
paras.cn: 当我最终放下手机时，我被迫面对我真正感受到的东西。像写日记、冥想和与亲人交谈这样的事情帮助我处理我感到的不适和焦虑。拥有远离社交媒体的空间和时间让我发现了最重要的一课，那就是如何在不使用社交媒体的情况下调节我的情绪。而那正是关键。

vocab.ex: It's important to put the phone down during dinner and talk to your family.
vocab.tr: 在晚餐时放下手机和家人交谈是很重要的。

vocab.ex: You need to confront your fears in order to overcome them.
vocab.tr: 你需要面对你的恐惧才能克服它们。

vocab.ex: She finds that journaling helps her to process her thoughts and feelings.
vocab.tr: 她发现写日记有助于她处理自己的思绪和感受。

vocab.ex: He spent the holidays surrounded by his loved ones.
vocab.tr: 他在亲人的环绕中度过了假期。

vocab.ex: He experienced some discomfort in his stomach after the large meal.
vocab.tr: 大餐后，他的胃感到一些不适。

vocab.ex: Learning to regulate your emotions is a key part of maturity.
vocab.tr: 学会调节你的情绪是成熟的关键部分。

vocab.ex: Communication is key to a successful relationship.
vocab.tr: 沟通是成功关系的关键。

paras.en: Once you understand what social media has been replacing in your life, you realize that filling those needs authentically is both challenging and incredibly rewarding. So ask yourself this, what are you really seeking when you open social media? Let me know in the comments below.
paras.cn: 一旦你理解了社交媒体在你生活中一直在取代什么，你就会意识到，真诚地填补那些需求既具挑战性，又非常有回报。所以问问自己这个问题，当你打开社交媒体时，你真正在寻求什么？在下面的评论中告诉我。

vocab.ex: Once you start, you won't be able to stop.
vocab.tr: 你一旦开始，就停不下来了。

vocab.ex: It's important to live your life authentically and be true to yourself.
vocab.tr: 真实地生活并忠于自己是很重要的。

vocab.ex: Climbing that mountain was a very challenging but rewarding experience.
vocab.tr: 攀登那座山是一次非常有挑战性但也有回报的经历。

vocab.ex: Teaching can be a very rewarding career.
vocab.tr: 教书可以是一个非常有回报的职业。

vocab.ex: Many people seek fame and fortune, but not all find it.
vocab.tr: 许多人寻求名利，但并非所有人都能找到。

title: The 2008 Financial Crisis: How It Happened

paras.en: September 2008, a 158-year-old bank collapsed overnight. $600 billion gone. Retirement accounts vanish. Millions lose jobs. But what if I told you the real cause started with a lie so simple, you could fit it on a billboard? "Why rent when you can own?" Cue the upbeat music.
paras.cn: 2008年9月，一家拥有158年历史的银行一夜之间倒闭。6000亿美元化为乌有。退休账户消失。数百万人失业。但如果我告诉你，真正的起因始于一个简单到可以写在广告牌上的谎言呢？“既然可以拥有，为什么要租房？”提示音响起，欢快的音乐随之而来。

vocab.ex: The company collapsed after the scandal.
vocab.tr: 丑闻曝光后，公司倒闭了。

vocab.ex: All his savings vanished overnight.
vocab.tr: 他的所有积蓄一夜之间消失了。

vocab.mean: 提示（某事发生）；给…提示信号
vocab.ex: Cue the lights.
vocab.tr: 提示灯光师打灯。

paras.en: It's 2002. America is still nursing a hangover from the dot-com crash. 9-11 just sucker punched the economy. And Wall Street? Kinda twitchy. But don't worry, the Federal Reserve has a plan. Slash interest rates to basically zero. Boom. Money's cheap. Borrowing is easy. And suddenly, everyone's favorite national pastime isn't baseball anymore. It's buying a house.
paras.cn: 那是2002年。美国仍在从互联网泡沫破裂的宿醉中恢复。9·11事件刚刚重创了经济。华尔街呢？有点焦虑不安。但别担心，美联储有一个计划。将利率大幅削减至基本为零。轰。钱变便宜了。借贷变得容易了。突然间，每个人最喜欢的国民消遣不再是棒球了。而是买房。

vocab.mean: 宿醉未醒（比喻从打击中恢复）
vocab.ex: The economy is still nursing a hangover from the recession.
vocab.tr: 经济仍在从衰退中恢复。

vocab.ex: The bad news really sucker punched him.
vocab.tr: 这坏消息真的给了他沉重一击。

vocab.ex: Investors are getting twitchy about the market volatility.
vocab.tr: 投资者对市场波动感到紧张不安。

vocab.ex: They had to slash prices to sell the goods.
vocab.tr: 他们不得不大幅降价来销售商品。

vocab.ex: Gardening is a popular pastime.
vocab.tr: 园艺是一种流行的消遣。

paras.en: Congratulations. You're approved for $500,000? But we make $40,000 a year. Not a problem. Adjustable rate. Balloon payment. Ninja loan. Wait, what's a ninja loan? No Income. No Job. No Assets. No problem. See, back in the early 2000s, home ownership wasn't just a roof and four walls. It was the American dream. Immense stability. Status. Suburban bliss.
paras.cn: 恭喜。你获批了50万美元贷款？但我们年收入只有4万美元。没问题。可调利率。气球式付款（期末大额偿还）。忍者贷款。等等，什么是忍者贷款？无收入。无工作。无资产。没问题。你看，在21世纪初，拥有住房不仅仅是拥有屋顶和四面墙。它是美国梦。巨大的稳定性。地位。郊区的幸福。

vocab.mean: 可调利率（通常指浮动利率抵押贷款）
vocab.ex: Adjustable rate mortgages can be risky if interest rates rise.
vocab.tr: 如果利率上升，可调利率抵押贷款可能会有风险。

vocab.mean: 气球式付款（贷款期末的一次性大额还款）
vocab.ex: He couldn't afford the balloon payment at the end of the loan term.
vocab.tr: 他付不起贷款期末的那笔大额款项。

vocab.mean: 忍者贷款（No Income, No Job, No Assets）
vocab.ex: Ninja loans were a hallmark of the subprime crisis.
vocab.tr: 忍者贷款是次贷危机的一个标志。

vocab.ex: They made an immense amount of money.
vocab.tr: 他们赚了巨额的钱。

paras.en: And the message being pumped through every ad, billboard and mortgage seminar was loud and clear. "Why rent when you can own?" Banks agreed. In fact, they agreed so hard they started throwing money at people like it was a game show and everyone was winning. Enter the subprime mortgage. Translation: Loans for people with bad credit? Unstable income or a vague idea of what money even is.
paras.cn: 每一个广告、广告牌和抵押贷款研讨会都在大声而清晰地灌输这个信息：“既然可以拥有，为什么要租房？”银行同意了。事实上，他们非常同意，以至于开始像游戏节目一样把钱扔给人们，每个人都在赢。次级抵押贷款登场了。翻译一下：给信用不良的人的贷款？收入不稳定或者对金钱概念模糊的人。

vocab.ex: Subprime mortgages carry higher interest rates due to higher risk.
vocab.tr: 次级抵押贷款由于风险较高，利率也较高。

vocab.ex: He had only a vague idea of how to proceed.
vocab.tr: 他对如何继续只有一个模糊的想法。

paras.en: Bad credit? No credit? Living in a van? You, sir, qualify for a luxury condo. Should I be worried about paying this back? Not your problem. If you default, we just sell the house for more. It was a housing gold rush. A frenzy. Everyone was buying. Prices skyrocketed. Your neighbor's house doubled in value in six months? Normal.
paras.cn: 信用差？没信用？住在货车里？先生，你有资格买豪华公寓。我应该担心还钱的事吗？不是你的问题。如果你违约，我们就把房子卖个更高的价钱。这是一场房地产淘金热。一种狂热。每个人都在买。价格飙升。你邻居的房子六个月内价值翻倍？很正常。

vocab.ex: You qualify for a lower interest rate.
vocab.tr: 你有资格获得更低的利率。

vocab.ex: If borrowers default, the bank seizes the property.
vocab.tr: 如果借款人违约，银行会扣押财产。

vocab.ex: The sale created a buying frenzy.
vocab.tr: 这次促销引发了抢购狂潮。

vocab.ex: Housing prices skyrocketed during the bubble.
vocab.tr: 泡沫期间房价猛涨。

paras.en: Even McDonald's part-timers and baristas with $5 in savings are approved for mortgages. Just a normal day in the 2000s. And the rules? Oh, those got launched straight out the window. Traditional lending standards? Too slow. Risk assessments? Too boring. Down payments? Optional. If you had a pulse, you had a mortgage.
paras.cn: 就连麦当劳的兼职员工和只有5美元存款的咖啡师也获批了抵押贷款。这只是21世纪初平常的一天。规则呢？哦，那些早就被抛到九霄云外了。传统的贷款标准？太慢了。风险评估？太无聊了。首付？可有可无。如果你有脉搏，你就能拿到抵押贷款。

vocab.mean: 抛之脑后；完全无视（通常用 throw out the window）
vocab.ex: Common sense was launched out the window.
vocab.tr: 常识被完全抛在脑后。

vocab.ex: Banks failed to do proper risk assessments.
vocab.tr: 银行未能进行适当的风险评估。

vocab.ex: They made a small down payment on the car.
vocab.tr: 他们为这辆车付了一小笔首付。

paras.en: People bought houses like ramen noodles. Lenders printed loans like monopoly money. Mortgage brokers made commissions faster than they could say bubble. Behind all the buzz was a blind faith that housing prices would always go up because they always had, until now. But beneath the open houses and granite countertops, a question lingered. What could possibly go wrong? Spoiler. Everything.
paras.cn: 人们买房像买方便面一样随意。贷款机构像印大富翁纸币一样发放贷款。抵押贷款经纪人赚取佣金的速度比说出“泡沫”这个词还要快。在所有这些喧嚣背后，是一种盲目的信念：房价总是会上涨，因为它们一直如此，直到现在。但在开放日和花岗岩台面之下，一个问题挥之不去。究竟会出什么错？剧透一下。一切都会出错。

vocab.mean: （像大富翁游戏里的）假钱；不值钱的钱
vocab.ex: They were spending cash like it was monopoly money.
vocab.tr: 他们花钱如流水，好像那是假钱一样。

vocab.ex: Brokers earn a commission on every sale.
vocab.tr: 经纪人从每笔销售中赚取佣金。

vocab.ex: Investors put blind faith in the market.
vocab.tr: 投资者对市场盲目信任。

vocab.ex: The smell of smoke lingered in the room.
vocab.tr: 房间里弥漫着烟味挥之不去。

paras.en: But we're just getting started. By 2005, buying a house wasn't about stability anymore. It was about flipping it like a pancake and hoping the next buyer paid double. Real estate wasn't shelter. It was a lottery ticket. "I teach phonics during the day and buy condos at night. I just bought my third house with zero down. I don't even live in any of them."
paras.cn: 但我们才刚刚开始。到了2005年，买房不再是为了稳定。而是像翻煎饼一样转手倒卖，并希望下一个买家付双倍的价钱。房地产不是住所。它是彩票。“我白天教自然拼读，晚上买公寓。我刚零首付买了第三套房子。我甚至不住在里面。”

vocab.ex: House flipping became a popular way to get rich quick.
vocab.tr: 炒房成为了一种快速致富的流行方式。

vocab.ex: Buying that stock was like buying a lottery ticket.
vocab.tr: 买那只股票就像买彩票一样。

vocab.ex: You can drive this car away for zero down.
vocab.tr: 你可以零首付把这辆车开走。

paras.en: This wasn't investing. It was a national obsession. Buy, flip, profit, repeat. And the more people joined in, the higher prices soared. The higher they soared, the more people rushed in. It was like trying to put out a fire by throwing gasoline at it and everyone had a match.
paras.cn: 这不是投资。这是全民痴迷。买入，倒手，获利，重复。参与的人越多，价格涨得越高。价格涨得越高，涌入的人就越多。这就像试图用汽油去灭火，而每个人手里都拿着一根火柴。

vocab.ex: Football is a national obsession in that country.
vocab.tr: 足球是那个国家的全民痴迷。

vocab.ex: Eagle soared high above the mountains.
vocab.tr: 鹰在群山之上高飞。（此处指价格飙升）

paras.en: But beneath the red-hot exterior, rot? Those subprime mortgages everyone was gorging on? They were bad. Like actually bad. High risk, low doc, barely verified debt. But Wall Street had a magic trick. They bundled all that junk together, slapped a label on it and sold it to investors as safe. Introducing mortgage-backed securities. Now with 80% more lies.
paras.cn: 但在火热的外表之下，是腐烂？每个人都在狼吞虎咽的那些次级抵押贷款？它们很糟糕。真的很糟糕。高风险，低文件要求（无需提供充分证明），几乎未经核实的债务。但华尔街有一个魔术。他们把所有那些垃圾捆绑在一起，贴上标签，然后作为安全资产卖给投资者。隆重介绍：抵押贷款支持证券。现在谎言含量增加了80%。

vocab.ex: There was a lot of rot beneath the surface of the company.
vocab.tr: 公司表面之下有很多腐败。

vocab.ex: The market gorged on cheap debt.
vocab.tr: 市场贪婪地吞噬着廉价债务。

vocab.mean: 低文件要求（指不需要借款人提供太多收入证明的贷款）
vocab.ex: Low doc loans are very risky for lenders.
vocab.tr: 低文件要求贷款对贷款人来说风险很大。

vocab.ex: MBS are investment products backed by a pool of mortgages.
vocab.tr: MBS是由抵押贷款池支持的投资产品。

paras.en: How do you make toxic loans look like gold? Easy. You get the ratings agencies to call them triple A. "This one's got bankrupt baristas and unemployed gym bros." "Ah, seems alright." Here's the part they don't put on the brochure. The ratings agencies were getting paid by the banks they were rating. It's like hiring a food critic, then telling them they won't get paid unless they call your raw chicken Michelin Starred.
paras.cn: 如何让有毒贷款看起来像金子？很简单。你让评级机构把它们评为AAA级。“这个里面有破产的咖啡师和失业的健身房兄弟。”“啊，看起来没问题。”这是他们没有写在宣传册上的部分。评级机构是由他们正在评级的银行支付费用的。这就像雇佣一个美食评论家，然后告诉他们，除非他们把你生的鸡肉称为米其林星级，否则他们就拿不到钱。

vocab.ex: The bank held billions in toxic assets.
vocab.tr: 银行持有数十亿的不良资产。

vocab.ex: Only the safest bonds get a Triple A rating.
vocab.tr: 只有最安全的债券才能获得AAA评级。

paras.en: Behind closed doors, the traders knew. This bundle is a sack of shit. But Wall Street wasn't done cooking. They took those shaky mortgage bundles and blended them into something even more complicated. Collateralized debt obligations. CDOs. Through financial alchemy, garbage loans became investment grade assets.
paras.cn: 在紧闭的门后，交易员们知道。这一捆就是一袋垃圾。但华尔街还没烹饪完。他们拿着那些摇摇欲坠的抵押贷款包，把它们混合成更复杂的东西。债务担保证券。CDO。通过金融炼金术，垃圾贷款变成了投资级资产。

vocab.ex: The business plan looks a bit shaky.
vocab.tr: 这个商业计划看起来有点不可靠。

vocab.ex: CDOs were a major instrument in the financial crash.
vocab.tr: CDO是金融崩溃中的主要工具。

vocab.mean: 炼金术（比喻化腐朽为神奇）
vocab.ex: It was pure financial alchemy.
vocab.tr: 这纯粹是金融炼金术。

paras.en: Actually, not everyone was fooled. A handful of investors, oddballs, skeptics, troublemakers, read the fine print. They saw the rot inside the boom. And instead of buying in, they asked a bold question. "What if we bet against it?" The problem? There was no product that lets you do that. So they marched into Wall Street's marble fortresses and said, "These loans are garbage. We want to short them. Can you build something that pays us if they go bust?"
paras.cn: 实际上，并非所有人都被愚弄了。少数投资者，那些怪人、怀疑论者、麻烦制造者，阅读了细则。他们看到了繁荣内部的腐烂。他们没有买入，而是提出了一个大胆的问题。“如果我们赌它输呢？”问题是？没有产品能让你那样做。所以他们走进华尔街的大理石堡垒说：“这些贷款是垃圾。我们要看空它们。你能造出一个如果它们破产就付钱给我们的东西吗？”

vocab.ex: He's a bit of an oddball, but he's a genius.
vocab.tr: 他有点怪，但他是个天才。
